Globetrotting: Irish Country Homes Suitable For a Swingin' St. Patrick's Day
Globetrotting: Irish Country Homes Suitable For a Swingin' St. Patrick's Day
Curbed NY
March 17, 2011 Thursday 6:00 PM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 Curbed
Length: 370 words
Byline: Rob Bear
Body
   Mar. 17, 2011 (Curbed delivered by Newstex) -- 
           
           Click the image above to view the full photogallery.
When budget airline mogul Tony Ryan finished his $140M renovation of Lyon Demesne, a 600-acre estate and 
1785 Georgian manor house (above), he probably wasn't keen on his rowdy compatriots holding their drunken St. 
Patrick's Day festivities on the property. Sadly, Ryan passed away in 2007 and his sons            put the immaculate 
mansion up for sale. With no takers at the initial $112M price, the brothers            trimmed it down to a slightly more 
accessible $70M. But, while $42M buys a lot of green beer, we thought we'd find some Irish country houses that 
don't require a billionaire's budget and could host a shamrock shindig without spoiling too much. 
?' In the village of Ashford, 40 minutes from downtown Dublin, lies Glanmore Castle, once the home of playwright 
John Millington Synge. The castle has now been divided into smaller homes and the prominent central tower is now 
for sale at $1.295M. Combining modern technology with classic details, the castle has solar panels on the roof. 
Despite the traditional Irish form, the four-bedroom castle loses points for its single bathroom.
?' The listing for Rathangan Lodge is short on interior photos,            suggesting a full renovation would probably be 
necessary, but the 1740 stone hunting lodge, built for the Earl of Leinster, boasts 11,000 square feet of interior 
space, perfect for a massive pre-renovation party. There are 33 rooms in total and four acres of land close to the 
village of Rathangan Town. $1.2M buys the chance to tackle a Tony Ryan-style renovation.
">
Globetrotting: Irish Country Homes Suitable For a Swingin' St. Patrick's Day
?' For those in need of a more privacy for their St. Patty's soiree, Phillipstown Manor boasts over 1,400 acres, but, 
much like Rathangan Lodge, requires a complete interior renovation. The stately facade and gorgeous country 
views should soften the pain of a $2.7M fixer-upper.
·            ??30m knocked off price of late Ryanair founder's home [Independent]
·            Lyon Demesne [Christie's]
·            Glanmore Castle [SherryFitz]
·            Rathangan Lodge [SherryFitz]
·            Phillipstown Manor [SherryFitz]

   Mar. 17, 2011 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, March 17th (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index ended the session lower by closing at 
$41.13, which represents -2.01% versus its previous day close. The airline index saw a broad decline with 1 out of 
12 airlines trading higher.
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) was the top performer of the sector today closing at $26.58 representing -0.04%. 
versus the previous trading session. Shares of Ryanair, the low fare European airline have defined support at 
$28.21 and resistance at $31.50.
US Airways (           NYSE:LCC) was also among the top performers, closed the trading session at $8.49 
representing -0.7% from its previous close. US Airways (NYSE:LCC) , the Phoenix based airline has calculated 
support and resistance levels at $8.42 and $9.38 respectively. The other top performer was Tam (           
NYSE:TAM), which closed the trading session at $20 representing -1.09% from the previous trading session.
The sector's worst performers include Delta (NYSE:DAL)  (           NYSE:DAL) that closed the trading session at 
$9.86 or -3.33% from the previous close. Shares of Delta, the largest airline in the world have defined support at 
$9.87 and resistance at $11.64. Also among the worst performers was SkyWest (           NASDAQ:SKYW), which 
closed the trading session at $15.76 representing -2.17% from the previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for April delivery was higher closing the trading session at $101.38 a barrel on the New York 
Mercantile Exchange higher by $3.4 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by traders 
as they usually correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is covered 
by the price of fuel.

TradersHuddle.com

Length: 157 words
Body
   Mar. 15, 2011 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, March 15th (TradersHuddle.com) - Unusual high volume detected on shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC 
(OOTC:RYAOF)  (NASDAQ:RYAAY)  (           NASDAQ:RYAAY), early in the trading session. Ryanair is currently 
trading lower by 2.73%, so definitely the sellers in control, as the stock's volume is on pace to break its average.
Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) provides low fare passenger airline services to destinations in Europe.
Ryanair has already traded 0.897 times its 3-month average volume, and has calculated support and resistance at 
$28.21 and $31.50 respectively. Traders like to use volume as their lie detector for price action moves through 
predefined trading ranges.
The overall market index S&P 500 is trading lower by -1.89% from its previous trading close, which means that 
Ryanair stock is underperforming the overall market.

Crude Oil Higher - Airlines Lower: RYAAY, GOL, AMR
Crude Oil Higher - Airlines Lower: RYAAY, GOL, AMR
TradersHuddle.com
March 14, 2011 Monday 5:02 PM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 TradersHuddle.com
Length: 305 words
Body
   Mar. 14, 2011 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, March 14th (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index ended the session lower by closing at 
$43.54, which represents -1.49% versus its previous day close. The airline index saw a broad decline with 1 out of 
12 airlines trading higher.
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) was the top performer of the sector today closing at $28.22 representing -0.11%. 
versus the previous trading session. Shares of Ryanair, the low fare European airline have defined support at 
$28.21 and resistance at $31.50.
Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes (           NYSE:GOL) was also among the top performers, closed the trading session 
at $12.95 representing -0.54% from its previous close. Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes (NYSE:GOL) , the low fare 
Brazilian domestic airline has calculated support and resistance levels at $12.59 and $13.75 respectively. The other 
top performer was AMR (NYSE:AMR), which closed the trading session at $6.56 representing -0.76% from the 
previous trading session.
The sector's worst performers include US Airways (NYSE:LCC) that closed the trading session at $8.87 or -3.38% 
from the previous close. Shares of US Airways, the Phoenix based airline have defined support at $7.71 and 
resistance at $9.30. Also among the worst performers was Southwest Airlines Co. (NYSE:LUV), which closed the 
trading session at $12.4 representing -2.52% from the previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for April delivery was higher closing the trading session at $101.39 a barrel on the New York 
Mercantile Exchange higher by $0.23 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by 
traders as they usually correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is 
covered by the price of fuel.

Spanish Airport Workers Plan Massive Series Of Strikes During Peak Travel Season
Spanish Airport Workers Plan Massive Series Of Strikes During Peak Travel 
Season
The Business Insider
March 9, 2011 Wednesday 6:56 AM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 The Business Insider
Length: 356 words
Byline: Gavan Reilly
Body
   Mar. 9, 2011 (The Business Insider delivered by Newstex) --
MILLIONS OF HOLIDAYMAKERS “ including thousands of Irish “ could see  their holiday plans ruined after staff in 
Spanish airports announced a  series of strikes from April to July.
The scheduled walkouts “  which are set to begin on April 20, and continue well into the peak  holiday season in 
July “ involves around 12,500 ground staff employed by  the state-owned airport authority, Aena.
They are walking out in  protest at state plans to privatise the authority, which could see many  of them lose their 
jobs, the Daily Telegraph reports.
The impact of  the strike action could spread further, the Telegraph adds, if the  countrys air traffic controllers joined 
in the actions “ because  flights to Portugal and Morocco would also be affected, given they  travel through Spanish 
airspace.
Airports in the Canary Islands  and the Balearic Islands are also affected by the proposed action.
Ryanair  said the action “ if it was to ultimately take place “ would see it  cancel around 300 flights over the Easter 
period, affecting the plans of  57,000 passengers across its European operations.
Chief executive  Michael OLeary            has called on the European Union to intervene in  the dispute, saying its 
effects stretch far beyond Spanish borders.
Spanish Airport Workers Plan Massive Series Of Strikes During Peak Travel Season
           The Independent reports, however, that the  disruption will not mean an immediate government response; 
when similar  wildcat strikes took place last year, the government indicated it would  not look favourably on any 
action intended to disrupt its vital tourism  industry.e
The 22 various day-long stoppages are led by three  trade unions which are opposed to the part-privatisation of the 
airport  authority, a move that            Reuters believes could raise as much as ??30bn for  the state.
The dates specified for the strikes are 20, 21, 24, 25  and 30 April; 2, 14, 15, 19 and 20 May; 13, 23 and 30 June; 1, 
2, 3, 4,  15 and 31 July; and 1, 15 and 31 August.
--------------
           This post previously appeared at TheJournal.ie
           Join the conversation about this story »

Body
   Mar. 9, 2011 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, March 9th (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index ended the session lower by closing at $43.81, 
which represents -1.25% versus its previous day close. The airline index had widespread weakness with 3 out of 12 
airlines trading higher.
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) was the top performer of the sector today closing at $28.97 representing 0.84%. versus 
the previous trading session. Shares of Ryanair, the low fare European airline have defined support at $28.21 and 
resistance at $31.50.
SkyWest (NASDAQ:SKYW) was also among the top performers, closed the trading session at $17.08 representing 
0.32% from its previous close. SkyWest, the regional airline servicing major airlines like Delta (NYSE:DAL)  and 
United has calculated support and resistance levels at $15.65 and $16.87 respectively. The other top performer 
was Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes (NYSE:GOL), which closed the trading session at $13.11 representing -0.91% 
from the previous trading session.
The sector's worst performers include US Airways (NYSE:LCC)  (           NYSE:LCC) that closed the trading session 
at $8.93 or -3.77% from the previous close. Shares of US Airways, the Phoenix based airline have defined support 
at $7.71 and resistance at $10.21. Also among the worst performers was Southwest Airlines Co. (NYSE:LUV)  (      
     NYSE:LUV), which closed the trading session at $12.31 representing -2.76% from the previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for April delivery was flat closing the trading session at $0 a barrel on the New York Mercantile 
Exchange flat by $0 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by traders as they usually 
correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is covered by the price of 
fuel.

11 out of 12 airlines trading higher.
US Airways (NYSE:LCC) was the top performer of the sector today closing at $9.28 representing 11.81%. versus 
the previous trading session. Shares of US Airways (NYSE:LCC) , the Phoenix based airline have defined support 
at $7.71 and resistance at $10.21.

(NYSE:LUV)  (           NYSE:LUV), which closed the trading session at $12.66 representing 7.56% from the previous 
trading session.

EasyJet Takes Yer Breath Away: Berlin v Tourists
EasyJet Takes Yer Breath Away: Berlin v Tourists
International Political Economy Zone
March 6, 2011 Sunday 7:04 PM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 International Political Economy Zone
Length: 1074 words
Byline: (Emmanuel)
Body
   Mar. 6, 2011 (International Political Economy Zone delivered by Newstex) -- 
 Turning and returning to some secret place to hide
Watching in slow motion as you turn to me and say
Take my breath away...
           OK, so L.A.-based 80s synthpop / New Wave band Berlin has little to do with their titular city aside from the 
name. The band's greatest hits (like its Top Gun            theme) came before the Berlin Wall collapsed. Now, 
though, beneficiaries of the Iron Curtain's demise are complaining that tourists are literally taking their breath away. 
Unbeknownst to many, Berlin is Europe's third largest tourist destination for overnight stays after Paris and London. 
And so the complaints rain down: We are being overrun by foreigners, punks, weirdos, etc. To use a regrettable 
term, some Berlin residents seek living space away from the travelling hordes. Like many others, this occurrence is 
another story of globalization. Whereas the European travel market was once dominated by national carriers 
charging higher air fares, low-cost airlines like (Greek) 
EasyJet and (Irish)            RyanAir have revolutionized the industry by standardizing planes, minimizing frills, and 
using secondary airports to offer bus fare-like rates. My Italian flatmate, for instance, flies out to visit different 
European cities three weekends each month.
           Some Europeans tend to be snobbish about tourists. From constantly bugging locals for directions to 
crowding out local transportation, there's always some minor gripe to be heard. As an IPE fiend, I happen to be in 
the minority that realizes the benefits of tourism for local industry and welcomes travellers unreservedly. Migration is 
a right of all peoples--read the Universal Declaration on Human Rights if you're in doubt. So, let people roam where 
they wish to provided they put some towards respecting local rules and customs. But it appears not everyone is 
happy about these events happening in Europe. The denizens of Berlin's Kreuzberg district, for instance, are            
crying foul:
EasyJet Takes Yer Breath Away: Berlin v Tourists
œHelp, the tourists are coming was the name of a gathering organized recently by the Green party in Kreuzburg. 
The turnout was good - over 120 people squeezed into a hall to talk about what they should do about the tourists 
who many long-time residents say are ruining the neighbourhood.
The bogeymen in their eyes have a profile: They are young and hail from England [yobs?], Sweden, or maybe Italy. 
In the morning they rattle sleeping residents out of their beds as they drag trolley suitcases over the cobblestones 
on their way to catch an early Ryanair flight. At night, they disturb the peace with loutish, alcohol-fuelled behaviour, 
littering the sidewalks with broken beer bottles and vomit. œWere not a zoo, said one young man in low-hanging 
jeans and a hoodie. œTourists need to head over to Alex or Kudamm, he added, referring to Alexanderplatz and 
Kurfürstendamm, two areas which have traditionally been main tourist magnets in the German capital.
But things are changing. The one-time alternative neighbourhood was once best known for its squats, drop-outs, 
punks and immigrants, not to mention the annual May Day demonstrations where leftists square off against police. 
But Kreuzberg is now firmly on the itinerary of many tourists, alongside the Brandenburg Gate and the TV Tower. 
With its many bars and clubs, hip reputation and cheap prices for accommodation and beer, Kreuzberg has become 
a prime destination for the low-cost-airline set.
It seems complains mirror those from the time of Berlin (the band). In addition, the practice of informal hotelling 
(think            Crashpadder or            Airbnb) is upsetting those in the formal sector:
œIve lived in Kreuzberg for 20 years, was a refrain often heard at the meeting, although it was hard to know 
whether people were angrier about the neighbourhood losing some of its gritty edge or at the techno blasting away 
in the all-night, open-air clubs along the Spree River. Indeed, some of the complaints by the self-styled œalternative 
crowd were reminiscent of the objections voiced by Swabian villagers upset at local punk shows in the 1980s...
There is also a thriving black-market hotel sector, which has the Berlin government concerned. Those are 
apartments that are regularly rented out by the day, week or month to young tourists or foreign students. The 
practice, while illegal because the owners lack the proper permits, is very popular. œBerlin has become the capital 
of the holiday rental, according to Burkhard Kieker, head of the city marketing agency, who said the trend pushes 
rents up and makes apartments scarce.
But the situation is unlikely to change any time soon, especially as Berlin keeps breaking its own record for tourist 
visits each year. In 2010, according to the citys tourist office, there were more than 21 million overnight stays and 
the total number of visitors topped 9 million, an increase of 9.5 percent over 2009. There are currently 112,000 hotel 
beds in the city; another 15,000 are planned...
œCity policy has simply been overwhelmed by all the development, admitted Gerhard Buchholz from the citys 
tourist board. But city authorities arent likely to discourage tourists from going to Kreuzberg or any other 
neighbourhood, despite complaints from locals. Berlin Mayor Klaus Wowereit is a big backer of the citys tourism 
sector, since industry-poor Berlin has few other sources of revenue. Tourism adds about ??9 billion to city coffers 
every year.
According to marketing chief Kieker, the Kreuzberg protests are overwrought and residents should be proud rather 
than annoyed that visitors from all over Europe come to experience something of the lives Kreuzbergers get to live 
every day. The neighbourhood has become a central part of Berlin, he said, instead of remaining the niche place it 
used to be. But it appears that for many long-term residents, living in that niche was just fine.
This problem is one I am sure most other cities would love. Having too many visitors! From where I come from, that 
would be worth putting up some inconvenience with. I suppose stricter zoning regulations can help overall, but still--
you may not know how good you've got it till its gone. In the wisdom of Berlin...
Through the hourglass I saw you 
In time you slipped away
EasyJet Takes Yer Breath Away: Berlin v Tourists
When the mirror crashed I called you
And turned to hear you say
If only for today--I am unafraid  
 Newstex ID: IPEZ-6800-101458601

   Mar. 5, 2011 (The Cranky Flier delivered by Newstex) --
           In the Trenches: Turnover Hurts “ Intuit Small Business Blog
 We had someone leave Cranky Concierge in the last couple weeks and that has made things difficult in the short 
run.
If you want better airline service, vote with your wallet “ CNN Out of the Office
 Its easy to complain, but if you really want to see airline service and policies change, vote with your wallet.
           Save Yourself (a Bundle): The Day of Ultra Low Cost Airlines Is Dawning “ BNET Headwinds
 With low cost carriers moving upmarket, the day of the ultra cost carrier may finally be here.  Think Ryanair 
blanketing the US.
           Rules to Encourage Airfare Ad Disclosure May Make Things Worse “ BNET Headwinds
 New rules to require fee disclosure in airline ads might just make things more confusing than they already are.
           Southwest Computer Meltdown Uncharacteristically Left Travelers In the Dark “ BNET Headwinds
 Southwest had a computer meltdown when the time came to switch over to its new frequent flier program.  But the 
strange thing was that their communication with the public was virtually non-existent.  It was very strange.
           In the Trenches: Managing from the Road “ Intuit Small Business Blog
 Ive spent the last week and a half on the road and that makes it hard to keep the business running. 
           Southwest recovers from 2 glitches, snarled flights “ Chicago Tribune
 I spoke with the Chicago Tribune about Southwests lack of communication during its recent meltdown.
Cranky on the Web (February 28 “ March 4)
           Why Southwest Went Silent During a Meltdown: It Didnt Want to Make Things Worse “ BNET Headwinds
 I spoke with Southwest after the computer melt down to find out why the airline chose the strategy it did.  I still have 
trouble with the path theyve chosen.
           Travel Insurance: The Revolution Wont Be Covered “ Business Week
 I was asked about travel insurance, and in general, I find the policies rarely cover what you want them to.

March 4, 2011 Friday 5:24 PM EST

All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 Market News Video
Length: 245 words
Body
View Video
 Mar. 4, 2011 (           Market News Video delivered by Newstex) -- 
European stocks are trading higher today, marking a second consecutive day of gains.
The Europe 2001 HOLDRS (EKH), which includes US-listed stocks of Europe-based companies, is trading flat 
Friday.
Top stocks in the fund include Millicom International Cellular (NASDAQ:MICC)  (MICC), ASM International (ASMI) 
and Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY).
The Vanguard MSCI Europe ETF (VGK) is trading down over .2% Friday, on the backs of top holdings Vodafone 
(NASDAQ:VOD)  (VOD), HSBC (NYSE:HBC)  (HBC), and BP (BP).
The iShares (NASDAQ:FEFN)  (NASDAQ:EUFN)  (NASDAQ:EMMT)  (NASDAQ:EMFN)  (NASDAQ:AXFN)  
(NYSE:CFT)  (NASDAQ:ACWX)  (NASDAQ:ACWI)  (NYSE:EMB)  (NYSE:TOK)  (NYSE:SCZ)  (NYSE:IGF)  
(NASDAQ:IFSM)  (NASDAQ:IFNA)  (NASDAQ:IFGL)  (NASDAQ:IFEU)  (NASDAQ:IFAS)  (NYSE:TLT)  
(NYSE:SHY)  (NYSE:WPS)  (NYSE:RXI)  (NYSE:MXI)  (NYSE:KXI)  (NYSE:JXI)  (NYSE:EXI)  (NYSE:EFA)  
(NYSE:EFV)  (NYSE:EFG)  (NYSE:TIP)  (NYSE:NYC)  (NYSE:DVY)  (NYSE:EEM)  (NYSE:KLD)  (NYSE:IWC)  
(NYSE:TLH)  (NYSE:SHV)  (NYSE:IEI)  (NYSE:GVI)  (NYSE:GBF)  (NYSE:CSJ)  (NYSE:CIU)  (NYSE:ITB)  
(NYSE:ITA)  (NYSE:IHI)  (NYSE:IHF)  (NYSE:IHE)  (NYSE:IEZ)  (NYSE:IEO)  (NYSE:IAT)  (NYSE:IAK)  
(NYSE:IAI)  (NYSE:IEV)  S&P Europe 350 Index Fund (IEV) trades down over .1%.
The 
preceding 
is 
a 
transcript 
of

Airline Stocks Wrap Up - Higher: SKYW, AMR, GOL
Airline Stocks Wrap Up - Higher: SKYW, AMR, GOL
TradersHuddle.com
February 28, 2011 Monday 6:02 PM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 TradersHuddle.com
Length: 323 words
Body
   Feb. 28, 2011 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, February 28th (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index ended the session higher by closing at 
$43.54, which represents 0.49% versus its previous day close. The airline index exhibited strong upside with 9 out 
of 12 airlines trading higher.
SkyWest (NASDAQ:SKYW) was the top performer of the sector today closing at $16.5 representing 4.9%. versus 
the previous trading session. Shares of SkyWest, the regional airline servicing major airlines like Delta (NYSE:DAL)  
and United have defined support at $15.25 and resistance at $16.38.
AMR (           NYSE:AMR) was also among the top performers, closed the trading session at $6.74 representing 
1.51% from its previous close. AMR, the owner and operator of the 2nd largest U.S. based airline and founder 
member of the Oneworld airline alliance has calculated support and resistance levels at $6.37 and $7.60 
respectively. The other top performer was Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes (NYSE:GOL), which closed the trading 
session at $13.46 representing 1.43% from the previous trading session.
The sector's worst performers include Ryanair (           NASDAQ:RYAAY) that closed the trading session at $28.52 
or -1.93% from the previous close. Shares of Ryanair, the low fare European airline have defined support at $28.23 
and resistance at $31.50. Also among the worst performers was JetBlue Airways (NASDAQ:JBLU)  (           
NASDAQ:JBLU), which closed the trading session at $5.7 representing -1.04% from the previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for April delivery was flat closing the trading session at $0 a barrel on the New York Mercantile 
Exchange flat by $0 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by traders as they usually 
correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is covered by the price of 
fuel.
 Newstex ID: TRHD-6828-101123007

Monday morning trivia
Monday morning trivia
Airline Biz Blog
February 28, 2011 Monday 11:00 AM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 Airline Biz Blog
Length: 108 words
Byline: Terry Maxon/Reporter
Body
   Feb. 28, 2011 (The Dallas Morning News delivered by Newstex) --
Which airline operates more Boeing (NYSE:BA)  737s than any other carrier? Why, Southwest Airlines (NYSE:LUV) 
, of course, with nearly 550 in its fleet.
But Southwest doesn't operate the Boeing 737-800, the most popular version of the next-generation Boeing 737. 
Southwest has 20 on order, but those aircraft don't begin arriving until next year.
Our question this week: Name the airline that operates more Boeing 737-800s than any other carrier in the world.
Answer below.
Answer: Dublin-based Ryanair, which just took delivery of its 300th Boeing 737-800.

Body
   Feb. 22, 2011 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, February 22nd (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index ended the session higher by closing at 
$43.81, which represents 47.24% versus its previous day close. The airline index had a broad rally with 12 out of 12 
airlines trading higher.
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) was the top performer of the sector today closing at $29.55 representing 48.9%. versus 
the previous trading session. Shares of Ryanair, the low fare European airline have defined support at $29.50 and 
resistance at $31.50.
SkyWest (           NASDAQ:SKYW) was also among the top performers, closed the trading session at $15.25 
representing 48.39% from its previous close. SkyWest, the regional airline servicing major airlines like Delta 
(NYSE:DAL)  and United has calculated support and resistance levels at $14.99 and $16.17 respectively. The other 
top performer was Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes (NYSE:GOL)  (           NYSE:GOL), which closed the trading 
session at $13.63 representing 48.06% from the previous trading session.
The sector's worst performers include Delta (           NYSE:DAL) that closed the trading session at $10.74 or 
46.46% from the previous close. Shares of Delta, the largest airline in the world have defined support at $11.32 and 
resistance at $12.13. Also among the worst performers was Alaska Air (           NYSE:ALK), which closed the 
trading session at $60 representing 46.64% from the previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for April delivery was flat closing the trading session at $0 a barrel on the New York Mercantile 
Exchange flat by $0 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by traders as they usually 
correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is covered by the price of 
fuel.

Launchpad London maiden journey: Midweek jaunt to Oslo
Launchpad London maiden journey: Midweek jaunt to Oslo
Gadling
February 21, 2011 Monday 10:30 AM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 Gadling
Length: 534 words
Byline: Alex Robertson Textor
Body
   Feb. 21, 2011 (AOL Weblogs delivered by Newstex) --
London is one dizzyingly well-connected city, uniquely positioned as a hub for air travel around Europe and beyond. 
The city has five airports--Heathrow, Gatwick, Stansted, Luton, and London City--six if you count tiny Southend. In 
2010, over 127 million passengers were carried through these airports. By way of contrast, Paris, the next biggest 
city in Europe in terms of passenger numbers, saw 83 million people pass through its two airports in 2010.
With this post, Gadling launches a new series designed to call attention to London as a launchpad for travel around 
Europe and beyond--from daytrip locations just outside the borders of Greater London to destinations as far afield 
as Dubai. We'll provide an overview of transportation options and also provide a budget-minded navigation of each 
destination.
First up: Oslo.
Several airlines fly from two London airports to Oslo. From London Heathrow, British Airways and SAS fly to Oslo-
Gardermoen, the city's main airport. From London Gatwick, Norwegian Air Shuttle flies to Oslo-Gardermoen and 
Ryanair flies to Oslo-Rygge, a secondary airport south of the city. When I searched for fares on Kayak, Ryanair's 
flights to Oslo-Rygge were cheapest, though I decided against this option in order to avoid having to deal with the 
lengthy transit time between the center of Oslo and Oslo-Rygge.
The cheapest flight I found to Oslo-Gardemoen was flown by Norwegian Air Shuttle, a Norwegian low-cost airline 
with good reach across Europe and an especially strong network throughout Scandinavia. My flight ran £95.60 
($153). I booked it just six days prior to departure.
My accommodation, organized through airbnb, cost me $152 for two nights. The $76 nightly charge breaks down as 
follows: $68 for the room plus a $16 airbnb service fee. Budget watchers will observe that I've spent $305 before 
arriving in Oslo.
My accommodation via airbnb amounts to one of the cheapest beds in Oslo, though single rooms at            
Ellingsens Pensjonat, the least expensive Oslo guesthouse I came across during research, are cheaper at 400 
NOK ($70) per night.
Launchpad London maiden journey: Midweek jaunt to Oslo
Bargain-hunters can find relatively low rates in private accommodation. Rooms in private homes can be booked at 
the train station tourist office on the day of requested accommodation. These rooms begin at around 300 NOK 
($53) per night, and there are dozens of private Oslo rooms on offer depending on season.
Want more options?            Bed & Breakfast Norway lists the following accommodations with single rooms available 
for under 400 NOK per night: the centrally-located            Den Blå Dør for 400 NOK ($70) and            Enerhaugen 
for 370 NOK ($65); and            Ambiose Bed & Breakfast for 370 NOK ($65) and Bed & Breakfast Poppe for 250 
NOK ($44), both of which are located on the outskirts of Oslo. During the summer, camping is another budget-
friendly accommodation option. From June 1 through September 1, sites for one or two people can be booked at       
     Ekeberg Camping's Oslo City Camp starting at 180 NOK ($32) per night.
           Continue reading Launchpad London maiden journey: Midweek jaunt to Oslo
 Newstex ID: AOLB-5155-100897693

Costa del Sol - 3 days in Spain
Costa del Sol - 3 days in Spain
Gadling
February 18, 2011 Friday 11:00 AM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 Gadling
Length: 187 words
Byline: Justin Delaney
Body
   Feb. 18, 2011 (AOL Weblogs delivered by Newstex) -- 
 
The Costa del Sol lazily stretches out along the southern Mediterranean coast of Spain. Not really committing to the 
industrious ambitions of            Barcelona or            Madrid, the coast is a land of perpetual siesta, where work 
orders are responded to with a simple "manana," and beaches gradually disappear into salty azure waters. It is the 
kind of place that convertibles were invented for.
To tackle it in 3 days would be a shame, but better than having not visited at all. To really cover the ground 
necessary along the Costa del Sol, an automobile is necessary. Luckily, car rentals in Spain are very affordable, as 
cheap as            15 Euros per day. Inexpensive flights also abound from all over Europe on            Easyjet and            
Ryanair. It is possible to fly to Malaga for under 20 U.S. dollars from Barcelona round-trip. Once you have arrived 
along this golden coast of white villages and luxurious beaches, there is much to do and see. Read on...
           Continue reading Costa del Sol - 3 days in Spain

Ryanair Upside Looming?
Ryanair Upside Looming?
TradersHuddle.com
February 14, 2011 Monday 5:03 AM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 TradersHuddle.com
Length: 221 words
Body
   Feb. 14, 2011 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, February 14th (TradersHuddle.com) - Shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (OOTC:RYAOF)  
(NASDAQ:RYAAY)  (           NASDAQ:RYAAY) ended the trading session higher by $0.41 or 1.38% from its 
previous close. Ryanair's price action formed what is considered to be a bullish engulfing candle that could very 
well signal continuation of trend or reversal on ongoing weakness.
Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) provides low fare passenger airline services to destinations in Europe.
Ryanair's recent stock range has been formed by a trough where calculated support was defined at $28.60 and by 
a peak that established the resistance level at $31.50, which could be used by traders planning their trades.
Traders wanting to establish a position in Ryanair or traders that are already holding the stock can use the bullish 
engulfing pattern to their advantage. The pattern provides a defined risk as it shows where the bears were able to 
push the stock down, before the bulls stepped in.
The bullish engulfing pattern is a leading indicator that provides an alert to the bulls that the trend will continue or 
that there is an immediate reversal to the short term weakness seen on the stock. Below an Engulfing Bullish 
Candle Illustration:

Airline Stocks Wrap Up - Lower: ALK, LFL, RYAAY
Airline Stocks Wrap Up - Lower: ALK, LFL, RYAAY
TradersHuddle.com
February 14, 2011 Monday 6:02 PM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 TradersHuddle.com
Length: 320 words
Body
   Feb. 14, 2011 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, February 14th (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index ended the session lower by closing at 
$46.23, which represents -0.48% versus its previous day close. The airline index exhibited weakness throughout 
with 5 out of 12 airlines trading higher.
Alaska Air (NYSE:ALK) was the top performer of the sector today closing at $64.51 representing 0.95%. versus the 
previous trading session. Shares of Alaska Air , the Airline serving destinations within the state of Alaska and the 
West Coast of the United States have defined support at $59.11 and resistance at $62.68.
Lan Airlines (           NYSE:LFL) was also among the top performers, closed the trading session at $28.9 
representing 0.42% from its previous close. Lan Airlines (NYSE:LFL) , the Chilean based airline has calculated 
support and resistance levels at $26.77 and $30.91 respectively. The other top performer was Ryanair (           
NASDAQ:RYAAY), which closed the trading session at $30.29 representing 0.23% from the previous trading 
session.
The sector's worst performers include JetBlue Airways (NASDAQ:JBLU)  (           NASDAQ:JBLU) that closed the 
trading session at $5.94 or -2.14% from the previous close. Shares of JetBlue Airways, the New York based 
discount airline have defined support at $5.78 and resistance at $7.13. Also among the worst performers was AMR 
(           NYSE:AMR), which closed the trading session at $7.17 representing -1.78% from the previous trading 
session.
Benchmark crude for March delivery was lower closing the trading session at $84.91 a barrel on the New York 
Mercantile Exchange lower by $-0.67 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by 
traders as they usually correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is 
covered by the price of fuel.

Watch Ryanair 's Ridiculous Video Teaching Belgian College Kids How To Pack A Carry-On
Watch Ryanair's Ridiculous Video Teaching Belgian College Kids How To 
Pack A Carry-On
The Business Insider
February 10, 2011 Thursday 1:03 PM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 The Business Insider
Length: 141 words
Byline: CheapOair
Body
   Feb. 10, 2011 (The Business Insider delivered by Newstex) --
Following a baggage fee dispute earlier this week that resulted in 100  Belgian students being kicked off a Ryanair 
flight, the budget airline  released a statement accompanied by a Youtube video which demonstrates             the 
proper way to pack a carry-on bag.
In the statement, the carrier suggested that Belgian universities add  the lesson to their curriculum œfollowing the 
unacceptable and unsafe  behavior of over 100 Belgian students last Saturday in Lanzarote.
The tongue-in-cheek video, which is set to the Benny Hill theme song,  shows a traveler impressively packing 
enough clothes for a two-week  vacation into one 10kg carry-on bag.

International Developer InCalabria Well Prepared for New Low Cost Airline Connections to Lamezia Terme
International Developer InCalabria Well Prepared for New Low Cost Airline 
Connections to Lamezia Terme
American Consumer News
February 8, 2011 Tuesday 3:19 AM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 American Consumer News
Length: 306 words
Byline: ACN Staff
Body
   Feb. 8, 2011 (American Consumer News delivered by Newstex) --
Tropea, Italy, February 08, 2011 “(PR.com)“ After centuries of isolation from the rest of the Italian mainland and 
Europe at large, the Southern Italian region Calabria is getting increasingly connected as the rest of the world finds 
out about its unique qualities such as its 800km stunning coastline, outstanding beaches, picturesque villages and 
the generally low prices and year round sunny, warm climate.
In 2011 the Airport of Sant Eufemia Lamezia Terme (SUF) in Calabria becomes a hub for Ryanair making the 
region accessible to low cost travellers from as far as Stockholm in Sweden, London in the UK, Brussels in 
Belgium, Dusseldorf in Germany and Barcelona in Spain. The domestic links in 2011 are Lamezia to Bergamo 
(Milan), Bologna, Pisa and Trapani.
Other popular routes are the seasonal flights with Air Transat from Toronto and the charter flights from Moscow.
"International property specialist InCalabria are well prepared," says Dennis Onstenk, the owner. "InCalabria is 
specialised in international direct marketing of Calabria property at competitive prices. In our central Tropea office in 
Italy our international team of consultants help buyers find the ideal property to suit their personal needs. We then 
assist in all matters concerning the purchase “ we are known to provide the best service in the business". The 
company currently has property on its books starting at Euro79.000 for a one bedroom apartment and Euro106.000 
for a two bedroom apartment.
InCalabria and their peers can look forward to a busy year as people from the United Kingdom and Northern 
Europe seek an escape from the doom and gloom and cold, dark winter months without breaking the bank.
They may just find it in sunny and affordable Calabria.
International Developer InCalabria Well Prepared for New Low Cost Airline Connections to Lamezia Terme
 Newstex ID: AMCN-5684-100503837

100 Students Mount a Bag-Fee Mutiny in Spain , Abroad a Ryanair Flight
100 Students Mount a Bag-Fee Mutiny in Spain, Abroad a Ryanair Flight
Hispanically Speaking News
February 7, 2011 Monday 1:35 PM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 Hispanically Speaking News
Length: 128 words
Body
   Feb. 7, 2011 (Hispanically Speaking News delivered by Newstex) -- 
           
Over hundred passengers mutinied a Ryanair flight from the Spanish Canary Islands when several passengers 
were asked to pay a fee for outsized carry-on luggage, as they were boarding the flight.
One male passenger, who was traveling with other Belgian college students, refused to pay then was denied 
access on to the plane.  Thats when his other traveling companions rushed the tarmac and mutinied the flight.  
Spanish police were called to calm the situation, eventually removing all 166 passengers.
Only 66 of the passengers were allowed to continue to their final destination in Belgium and only after a three hour 
delay.
Published in Notitas de Noticias

Ryanair flight grounds 104 Belgian students after luggage fee fight
Ryanair flight grounds 104 Belgian students after luggage fee fight
Gadling
February 6, 2011 Sunday 11:30 AM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 Gadling
Length: 226 words
Byline: Scott Carmichael
Body
   Feb. 6, 2011 (AOL Weblogs delivered by Newstex) -- 
 Another day, another chance for Ryanair to make the news. Today's incident comes from the Spanish            
Canary Islands where a plane full of passengers had to be emptied after a mass fight broke out.
The fight happened after one passenger got angry when he was told he'd need to pay to have his oversize bag 
checked. This didn't go down well with him, or with the large number of fellow students he was traveling with.
A fight broke out and the flight crew called for assistance. Police arrived, and all 168 passengers were told to leave 
the plane.
According to the news report, all passengers had to be "identified", which probably means the flight crew pointed 
out which of them were involved in the scuffle.
Of those 168, only 64 were allowed to fly home to Belgium. The rest of them were forced to spend the night in 
Lanzarote. None of the students stranded on the island had any money left, so the Belgian Ministry of Foreign 
Affairs had to intervene, forcing Ryanair to fly the students back. This will take several days as the group is being 
flown back five or six at a time.
Thankfully for Ryanair, this is one incident that can't be blamed on them - and those passengers stuck on the island 
deserve all the inconvenience they can get.
[photo: AFP/Getty Images]
 Newstex ID: AOLB-5155-100445917

The railways renaissance
The railways renaissance
Adam Smith Institute blog
February 3, 2011 Thursday 12:00 AM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 Adam Smith Institute blog
Length: 322 words
Byline: sam@adamsmith.org (Nigel Hawkins)
Body
   Feb. 3, 2011 (Adam Smith Institute blog delivered by Newstex) --
In terms of passenger use, the railways are enjoying a ˜golden age. Figures earlier in the week showed that 1.32 
billion passenger journeys were made last year. Not only was this figure well up on 2009 but it was also the highest 
railway use since the mid-1920s (if the 1939-45 war period is excluded).
Inevitably, this scenario begs the question as to how future rail demand levels can be met. In the long-term, the 
Government plans to modernise the network, with the c£34 billion High Speed 2 project being key. Initially, the latter 
is scheduled to run between London and Birmingham “ and eventually to Manchester and Leeds. Since High Speed 
2 is unlikely to be operational before 2026, other solutions should be explored.
Like many markets, the UK rail network suffers both from excess demand “ packed carriages to London during 
commuting hours “ and from inadequate demand “ near empty carriages in some rural areas. The market should be 
allowed to make its own adjustments. This philosophy should be embraced “ at least in part - by the planned 
franchise amendments. Longer franchises and more scope for the franchise holders to adjust to consumer demand 
are anticipated.
Much of the capacity concern focuses on both the West Coast and East Coast Main Lines, where trains are often 
very crowded. Why cant these standard services run regularly throughout the night, with very cheap tickets being 
on offer which would be highly attractive to students?
By adopting a Ryanair booking policy, the 1am London Kings Cross to Edinburgh fare, for example, could be 
minimal “ just like its fare to an obscure Polish city on a Tuesday in deep winter. At peak hours, market demand 
would ramp up fares. After all, many people currently fly during the night as well as visit 24-hour Tesco shops. Will 
24-hour rail travel eventually become the norm?
The railways renaissance
 Newstex ID: SMIT-0001-100368932  
Notes

Approaching Resistance - Ryanair
Approaching Resistance - Ryanair
TradersHuddle.com
February 3, 2011 Thursday 11:20 PM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 TradersHuddle.com
Length: 190 words
Body
   Feb. 3, 2011 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
New York, February 3rd (TradersHuddle.com) - Shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (OOTC:RYAOF)  (           
NASDAQ:RYAAY) are trading very close to calculated resistance at $31.50 with the current price action closing at 
just $30.78 placing the stock near levels that make it difficult to buy.
Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) provides low fare passenger airline services to destinations in Europe.
Ryanair's current stock range is defined by current calculated support defined at $28.60 and by the resistance level 
at $31.50, the stock is clearly over-extended from support, making it difficult to establishing new long positions at 
this level.
Traders don't have a clear entry point for Ryanair, as the stock is well above support, however, as the stock pulls 
back towards $28.60 it will definitely provide a reference point to establish a trade. On the other hand if the stock 
decides to break above resistance level at $31.50 then traders will get an opportunity to enter Ryanair stock by 
establishing a position as the stock moves to a higher range.

Airline Stocks Wrap Up - Higher: ALK, SKYW, RYAAY
Airline Stocks Wrap Up - Higher: ALK, SKYW, RYAAY
TradersHuddle.com
February 1, 2011 Tuesday 6:02 PM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 TradersHuddle.com
Length: 315 words
Body
   Feb. 1, 2011 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, February 1st (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index ended the session higher by closing at 
$45.92, which represents 1.35% versus its previous day close. The airline index exhibited strong upside with 9 out 
of 12 airlines trading higher.
Alaska Air (NYSE:ALK) was the top performer of the sector today closing at $62.25 representing 5.08%. versus the 
previous trading session. Shares of Alaska Air , the Airline serving destinations within the state of Alaska and the 
West Coast of the United States have defined support at $59.02 and resistance at $63.15.
SkyWest (NASDAQ:SKYW) was also among the top performers, closed the trading session at $15.52 representing 
3.12% from its previous close. SkyWest, the regional airline servicing major airlines like Delta (NYSE:DAL)  and 
United has calculated support and resistance levels at $15.00 and $16.20 respectively. The other top performer 
was Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY), which closed the trading session at $31.42 representing 2.81% from the previous 
trading session.
The sector's worst performers include JetBlue Airways (NASDAQ:JBLU) that closed the trading session at $5.83 or 
-2.83% from the previous close. Shares of JetBlue Airways, the New York based discount airline have defined 
support at $5.71 and resistance at $7.13. Also among the worst performers was Tam (NYSE:TAM), which closed 
the trading session at $21.94 representing -0.27% from the previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for March delivery was lower closing the trading session at $90.61 a barrel on the New York 
Mercantile Exchange lower by $-1.58 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by 
traders as they usually correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is 
covered by the price of fuel.

Ryanair CEO Rags On British Airways, Air France To Investors
Ryanair CEO Rags On British Airways, Air France To Investors
The Business Insider
January 31, 2011 Monday 1:37 PM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 The Business Insider
Length: 237 words
Byline: Tim Human
Body
   Jan. 31, 2011 (The Business Insider delivered by Newstex) --
Michael OLeary, chief executive of budget airline            Ryanair, was his usual feisty self today during a            
conference call accompanying his companys Q3 results.
The no-frills airline boss, famous for his            outspoken style, used the call to            let fly at competitors, tick off 
ignorant journalists and enjoy some banter with the analysts who came on to ask questions. Below weve gathered 
some soundbites:
On Air Frances new base in Marseille
˜We havent heard anything about Air France “ it already has a base in Marseille. So Im not sure what it is it has 
announced but I suspect its some dressed-up, not-very-important development.
On the situation in Egypt (where Ryanair doesnt fly)
˜Weve been fending off questions about the impact of the Egyptian crisis on us all morning. Its like, what are you 
talking about?
On fare rises
˜I see the kind of commentary coming out of the other airlines: well, were at the big airports so were going to get 
more business passengers and our fares will rise very significantly. I mean if that bullsh*t was true, BA would be the 
worlds most profitable, most successful airline. Its not.
On analysts with two questions
˜Robert, we charge extra for double questions!
Source:            Ryanair's Q3 results conference call

   Jan. 31, 2011 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, January 31st (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index ended the session lower by closing at 
$45.31, which represents -1.04% versus its previous day close. The airline index had widespread weakness with 3 
out of 12 airlines trading higher.
JetBlue Airways (NASDAQ:JBLU) was the top performer of the sector today closing at $6 representing 2.04%. 
versus the previous trading session. Shares of JetBlue Airways, the New York based discount airline have defined 
support at $6.22 and resistance at $7.13.
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) was also among the top performers, closed the trading session at $30.56 representing 
1.02% from its previous close. Ryanair, the low fare European airline has calculated support and resistance levels 
at $28.60 and $31.89 respectively. The other top performer was SkyWest (NASDAQ:SKYW), which closed the 
trading session at $15.05 representing -0.59% from the previous trading session.
The sector's worst performers include Tam (NYSE:TAM) that closed the trading session at $22 or -6.14% from the 
previous close. Shares of Tam, the Brazil based airline have defined support at $23.08 and resistance at $25.26. 
Also among the worst performers was Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes (NYSE:GOL), which closed the trading 
session at $14.48 representing -2.49% from the previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for February delivery was flat closing the trading session at $88.86 a barrel on the New York 
Mercantile Exchange flat by $0 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by traders as 
they usually correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is covered by 
the price of fuel.

Body
   Jan. 31, 2011 (Minyanville delivered by Newstex) --
With oil and inflation each marching inexorably up and the Middle East again ablaze, its as if were slowly going 
back to the decade of leisure suits. No surprise then that an iconic 70²s sitcom summed up equity action. When it 
came to winning weeks, the Dow did indeed conclude            Eight is Enough, its 0.41% slippage on Cairo concerns 
snapping a two month upturn. (Also read            Revolt in Egypt: Two Investment Scenarios.) Accordingly, the 30-
year bond yield surged to a nine month high just as one Bond            bid us his swan song, and similar safe haven 
buying sent gold to its best single session showing for three months on Friday. (Making King Tut worth much more, 
always            assuming he survives the week intact.) Standout stocks in otherwise uninspiring market action 
included Natuzzi SpA (NTZ), the Bari based sofa and sectional maker surging 19.9% with Italians evidently inspired 
by the $63 million Englishmen recently            uncovered in their couches.
Though he can well afford it with corn surging while wheat is at its highest level in 29 months, a Kansas City pitcher 
walked away from $12 million. This as Goldman Sachs (GS)            super-sized the salary of its CEO in a filing, 
announced late on a Friday afternoon for some strange reason. It comes as Lloyd Blankfeins track record for œ           
doing Gods work could be questioned, what with the            foreclosure rate rising ominously at religious 
institutions. Today in economics, Januarys Chicago Purchasing Managers Index is out at 9:45AM Eastern. On the 
corporate front another full week for fourth quarter earnings is underway with Anadarko Petroleum (APC), Exxon 
Mobil (XOM), Gannett (GCI), Honda Motor (HMC), McKesson (MCK), and Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) all due to 
report results.

Swift Transportation (SWFT): The stock is initiated with an Outperform at Wells Fargo.

from-Neutral boost.

price.

objective is $65.

Ryanair 's Micheal O'Leary delivers earnings report as only he can pull off
Ryanair's Micheal O'Leary delivers earnings report as only he can pull off
Gadling
January 31, 2011 Monday 1:30 PM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 Gadling
Length: 191 words
Byline: Scott Carmichael
Body
   Jan. 31, 2011 (AOL Weblogs delivered by Newstex) -- 
Ryanair CEO            Michael O'Leary is probably the most insane airline CEO in the world - but at the same time, 
he's probably one of the most brilliant. Even when global airlines went into a panic during the recent economic 
meltdown, his airline stayed profitable, and his numbers usually outshine those of many legacy carriers.
So, when Mr. O'Leary held a conference call with members of the press to discuss his Q3 earnings report, it was 
filled with everything we've come to expect from him.
Inside Investor Relations picked some of the juiciest quotes,including him making fun of journalists, calling claims 
by British Airways "bullsh*t" and mocking Air France. Their take on the call            can be found here.
Mockery aside, the airline did have some bad news to report - it posted a $14 million loss in Q3 of 2010, mostly due 
to the major travel disruptions after record snowfall in Europe. Add the fallout from Icelandic volcano Eyjafjallajökull, 
and 2010 was a pretty lousy year for Ryanair.
Stuff like this only makes me love Mr. O'Leary even more.
 Newstex ID: AOLB-5155-100295353

TradersHuddle.com
January 28, 2011 Friday 6:02 PM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 TradersHuddle.com
Length: 305 words
Body
   Jan. 28, 2011 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, January 28th (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index ended the session lower by closing at 
$45.79, which represents -4.31% versus its previous day close. The airline index saw a broad decline with 1 out of 
12 airlines trading higher.
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) was the top performer of the sector today closing at $30.25 representing -0.62%. 
versus the previous trading session. Shares of Ryanair, the low fare European airline have defined support at 
$28.60 and resistance at $31.89.
Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes (NYSE:GOL) was also among the top performers, closed the trading session at 
$14.85 representing -2.88% from its previous close. Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes, the low fare Brazilian domestic 
airline has calculated support and resistance levels at $15.38 and $16.46 respectively. The other top performer was 
Lan Airlines (NYSE:LFL), which closed the trading session at $28.34 representing -3.57% from the previous trading 
session.
The sector's worst performers include JetBlue Airways (NASDAQ:JBLU) that closed the trading session at $5.88 or 
-8.13% from the previous close. Shares of JetBlue Airways, the New York based discount airline have defined 
support at $6.22 and resistance at $7.13. Also among the worst performers was US Airways (NYSE:LCC), which 
closed the trading session at $10.16 representing -8.05% from the previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for February delivery was flat closing the trading session at $88.86 a barrel on the New York 
Mercantile Exchange flat by $0 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by traders as 
they usually correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is covered by 
the price of fuel.

In the cheap seats
In the cheap seats
Gulliver
January 28, 2011 Friday 12:03 PM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 Gulliver
Length: 183 words
Body
   Jan. 28, 2011 (The Economist delivered by Newstex) --
           A PIECE in this week's Economist looks at recent changes in the budget-airline market and the efforts 
carriers are making to pep up slowing growth rates. Ryanair, for example, is trying to make greater use of primary 
airports in order to "concentrate less on increasing traffic and more on extracting larger amounts of money from 
each passenger". And Air Berlin is also taking ideas from traditional airlines.
Air Berlin now arranges its timetables to encourage transfers at its Berlin Tegel, Düsseldorf and Palma hubs, like a 
traditional network carrier. It also has a frequent-flyer programme. Through its Niki associate in Austria, the airline 
even offers a direct flight from Berlin to Dubai three times a week. It is discussing a co-operation deal with Emirates, 
so that passengers from the Gulf carrier can connect in Vienna to fly to other European cities. Air Berlin is also 
joining the oneworld alliance based around British Airways and American Airlines. (NYSE:AMR) 
Read the whole article

represents -1.2% versus its previous close. The airline index is seeing a broad decline with 2 out of 12 airlines 
trading higher.
SkyWest (NASDAQ:SKYW) is the top performer of the sector so far, trading at $15.32 representing 0%. versus the 
previous trading session. Shares of SkyWest, the regional airline servicing major airlines like Delta and United have 
defined support at $15.00 and resistance at $16.78.
Lan Airlines (NYSE:LFL) is also among the top performers, currently trading at $29.69 representing -0.64% from its 
previous close. Lan Airlines, the Chilean based airline has calculated support and resistance levels at $28.86 and 
$30.91 respectively. The other top performer is Alaska Air (NYSE:ALK), which is trading at $60.28 representing -
0.79% from the previous trading session.

close. Shares of Delta, the largest airline in the world have defined support at $11.11 and resistance at $13.21. Also 
among the worst performers is Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY), which is currently trading at $29.93 representing -
2.19% from the previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for February delivery is trading flat trading at $88.86 a barrel on the New York Mercantile

correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is covered by the price of 
fuel.

Ryanair Waiting for Direction
Ryanair Waiting for Direction
TradersHuddle.com
January 24, 2011 Monday 5:57 AM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 TradersHuddle.com
Length: 295 words
Body
   Jan. 24, 2011 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, January 24th (TradersHuddle.com) - Shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (OOTC:RYAOF)  
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) closed the trading day lower by $0.4 or -1.36% from its previous close. Ryanair's shares price 
action formed what is considered to be a doji close, where the open and close prices are very close to each other, 
mainly signaling an indecision between buyers and sellers.
Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) provides low fare passenger airline services to destinations in Europe.
Ryanair's current stock range is defined by a trough, which marks calculated support at $28.60 and by a peak that 
marked the resistance point at $31.89. These levels are closely watched by traders managing their positions.
Traders wanting to establish a position in Ryanair or traders that are already holding the stock can use the doji 
close to their advantage, since the pattern present a short term pause in the stock's price action. This pause results 
in an entry point for traders depending of which way the stock resolves this short term indecision.
Doji are important candlesticks that provide information on their own and as components in a number of important 
patterns. Doji form when a security's open and close are virtually equal. The length of the upper and lower shadows 
can vary and the resulting candlestick looks like a cross, inverted cross or plus sign. Alone, doji are neutral patterns.
Any bullish or bearish bias is based on preceding price action and future confirmation. In the case of Ryanair, given 
that the stock finished the session lower, bears should monitor the stock, as it could reverse if it manages to trade 
above today's intraday high. Below a Doji illustration:
 Newstex ID: TRHD-6828-100092975  
Ryanair Waiting for Direction

the previous trading session. Shares of Ryanair, the low fare European airline have defined support at $28.60 and 
resistance at $31.89.

closed the trading session at $15.67 representing 0.06% from the previous trading session.

HSBC ( NYSE : HBC) Analysts Upgraded Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ : RYAAY ) to œOverweight
HSBC (NYSE: HBC) Analysts Upgraded Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ: 
RYAAY) to œOverweight
American Consumer News
January 21, 2011 Friday 3:27 PM EST
Copyright 2011 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2011 American Consumer News
Length: 267 words
Byline: ACN Staff
Body
   Jan. 21, 2011 (American Consumer News delivered by Newstex) --
HSBC (NYSE: HBC) research analysts upgraded Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ: RYAAY) from a œneutral rating 
to an œoverweight rating in a research note issued to investors on Monday.
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ: RYAAY)s stock traded down 0.95% on Friday, hitting $29.22. Ryanair Holdings plc 
(OOTC:RYAOF)  has a 52 week range of $21.55 to $33.38. The stocks 50-day moving average is $30.77 and its 
200-day moving average is $30.46. Analysts predict on average that Ryanair Holdings plc will post $-0.34 earnings 
per share next quarter. The company has a market cap of $8.687 billion and a P/E (price-to-earnings ratio) of 18.44.
About Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ: RYAAY)
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is the holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates a 
low-fares, scheduled passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, Continental Europe and Morocco. At June 30, 2010, with its operating fleet of 250 Boeing (NYSE:BA)  
737-800 aircraft, Ryanair offered approximately 1,300 scheduled short-haul flights per day serving 155 airports 
throughout Europe and Morocco, and flying approximately 1,100 routes. The Company also holds a 29.8% interest 
in Aer Lingus Group plc (OOTC:AELGF)  (Aer Lingus). During the Fiscal year ended March 31, 2010 (fiscal 2010), 
Ryanair announced 356 new routes originating from Belgium, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Lithuania, Malta, 
Norway, Portugal, Slovakia, Spain, Sweden and the United Kingdom.
 Newstex ID: AMCN-5684-100040030  
Notes

   Dec. 27, 2010 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, December 27th (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index ended the session higher by closing at 
$46.86, which represents 0.12% versus its previous day close. The airline index was mixed with 7 out of 12 airlines 
trading higher.

resistance at $14.38.
AMR (NYSE:AMR) was also among the top performers, closed the trading session at $7.89 representing 1.41% 
from its previous close. AMR, the owner and operator of the 2nd largest U.S. based airline and founder member of 
the Oneworld airline alliance has calculated support and resistance levels at $7.54 and $8.11 respectively. The 
other top performer was Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY), which closed the trading session at $30.43 representing 1.4% 
from the previous trading session.
The sector's worst performers include Alaska Air (NYSE:ALK) that closed the trading session at $56.55 or -1.48% 
from the previous close. Shares of Alaska Air , the Airline serving destinations within the state of Alaska and the 
West Coast of the United States have defined support at $52.66 and resistance at $59.59. Also among the worst 
performers was Tam (NYSE:TAM), which closed the trading session at $23.98 representing -1.28% from the 
previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for January delivery was lower closing the trading session at $88.7 a barrel on the New York 
Mercantile Exchange lower by $-0.11 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by 
traders as they usually correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is 
covered by the price of fuel.
Sector Wrap Up - Arlines Higher: DAL, AMR, RYAAY
 Newstex ID: TRHD-6828-52103666

Philippines ' Economics of Excessive Vacation
Philippines' Economics of Excessive Vacation
International Political Economy Zone
December 26, 2010 Sunday 2:35 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 International Political Economy Zone
Length: 646 words
Byline: (Emmanuel)
Body
   Dec. 26, 2010 (International Political Economy Zone delivered by Newstex) -- 
           Is too much vacation bad? Working in academia right now, I must unreservedly state that one of its perks is 
having more free time once the semester is out. However, for the clock puncher / office slave classes, things are 
not as straightforward. Take the example of the Philippines. Inheriting a "hectic" holiday schedule from its colonial 
masters of manana the Spanish, things have gotten out of hand in recent years. In a bid to supposedly increase 
vacation trips and decrease disruptions due to holidays, it has had a habit of moving holidays that fall midweek to 
Fridays and Mondays.
However, the economic benefits of doing so are not clear. Indeed, industry voices and the president himself are 
looking to reduce the number of paid holidays to a more manageable 16 [!] days--still world-leading by any 
standard, though:
With less than two weeks left before Christmas this year, the Philippine government unveiled a holiday gift to its 
people: Friday would be day off to mark Christmas Eve, and a second public holiday, in honor of a national martyr, 
would be observed on Monday, Dec. 27.
The result was a windfall four-day weekend. But instead of invoking cheer, such surprises are increasingly being 
met with grumbles from Philippine business leaders, its president and even some of its heavily vacationed workers. 
The Dec. 12 holiday shuffle was part of a distinctly Philippine way of handing out and scheduling days off”offering 
many official vacation days, and often rearranging them at the last minute to fall on the nearest Friday or Monday.
The country's leaders have hoped the long weekends will encourage citizens to shop and travel, boosting retail 
sales and the local tourism industry. Former Philippine President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo embraced the strategy, 
dubbed "holiday economics," and was often photographed on long weekends kitted out in a wetsuit for some 
surfing, or visiting her home province [of Pampanga], north of Manila.
Philippines ' Economics of Excessive Vacation
Not working out that way. First, disposable income is not high enough to encourage jaunts elsewhere in the 
Philippines during long weekends. Let's just say there isn't yet a habit of going around Europe on cheap Easyjet or 
Ryanair weekend trips:
The tourism industry in the Philippines accounts for 8% of total gross domestic product, compared with nearly 
double that in nearby Thailand, so shuffling and adding holidays to benefit the travel industry would have a relatively 
slight knock-on effect on the broader economy. Many Filipino workers don't earn enough to go off on lavish jaunts 
around the country anyway. The per capita income here averages under $2,000 a year. Even those with solid 
professional jobs struggle to make ends meet, and don't necessarily get paid on national holidays.
Second, all these paid holidays are, according to some, making the Philippines less attractive as a business 
destination compared to its neighbouring countries which get by on less R&R:
Fewer holidays could help stir more foreign interest in the economy. In a recent study, the Joint Foreign Chambers 
of Commerce warned that the number of holidays and their erratic timing dissuades some foreign companies from 
coming here. Under Philippine law, businesses have to double daily wages for those who work through the main 
public holidays, or pay up to 50% on other selected holidays. That is a powerful deterrent as lower-cost locations 
such as Bangladesh and Vietnam open up to the global economy.
Already, foreign direct investment is the lowest of the major Southeast Asian countries, totaling $1.95 billion in 2009 
compared with $4.88 billion in Indonesia, $7.60 billion in Vietnam and $5.96 billion in Thailand.Maybe too much 
vacation isn't good. But then again, I'm not exactly in a position to gripe, right?  
 Newstex ID: IPEZ-6800-52049654  
Notes

$47.35, which represents -1.17% versus its previous day close. The airline index saw a broad decline with 2 out of 
12 airlines trading higher.
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) was the top performer of the sector today closing at $30.23 representing 1.07%. versus 
the previous trading session. Shares of Ryanair, the low fare European airline have defined support at $29.59 and 
resistance at $31.59.
Southwest Airlines Co. (NYSE:LUV) was also among the top performers, closed the trading session at $13.09 
representing -0.08% from its previous close. Southwest Airlines Co. , the domestic discount airline that focuses in 
short haul and high frequency has calculated support and resistance levels at $12.31 and $14.32 respectively. The 
other top performer was JetBlue Airways (NASDAQ:JBLU), which closed the trading session at $6.64 representing -
0.56% from the previous trading session.
The sector's worst performers include Tam (NYSE:TAM) that closed the trading session at $24.06 or -3.26% from 
the previous close. Shares of Tam, the Brazil based airline have defined support at $23.77 and resistance at 
$25.92. Also among the worst performers was Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes (NYSE:GOL), which closed the 
trading session at $14.69 representing -2.46% from the previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for January delivery was lower closing the trading session at $88.7 a barrel on the New York 
Mercantile Exchange lower by $-0.11 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by 
traders as they usually correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is

New York, December 22nd (TradersHuddle.com) - Shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (OOTC:RYAOF)  
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) are trading very close to calculated support at $29.59 with current price action closing at just 
$29.91 places the stock price near levels where traders will start paying attention.
Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) provides low fare passenger airline services to destinations in Europe.
Ryanair's current stock range is defined by current calculated support defined at $29.59 and by the resistance level 
at $31.59, which should be used by traders planning their trades.
Traders wanting to establish a position should place close attention to Ryanair's price action, and establish a 
position as close to support as possible, but only after buying materializes. Traders should understand that the 
resistance point at $31.59 might limit their upside, however if the stock breaks resistance, it could be a good point to 
add to the position.

ArgusCarHire.com and Ryanair
American Consumer News

Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 American Consumer News
Length: 276 words
Byline: admin
Body
   Dec. 21, 2010 (American Consumer News delivered by Newstex) --
 ArgusCarHire.com Retracts Press Release Regarding Association between ArgusCarHire.com and Ryanair
A Press Release Retraction from ArgusCarHire.com: Regarding Association between ArgusCarHire.com and 
Ryanair
 (PRWEB) December 21, 2010
 This retraction is in response to a press release issued by ArgusCarHire on December 10, 2010, entitled œPay 
Less for Ryanair Car Hire with Arguscarhire.com.
The above mentioned press release inadvertently and incorrectly implied that there was an association between 
Ryanair and ArgusCarHire.com. ArgusCarHire.com would like to correct this implication by stating unambiguously 
that there is no relationship between Ryanair and ArgusCarHire.com. Also to parties who considered the press 
release to be disingenuous ArgusCarHire.com would like to state there was no intent to misrepresent or expoit 
Ryanairs branding in any way.
About ArgusCarHire.com:
Argus Car Hire was established in 1959, online since 1996. ArgusCarHire is recognised as one of the worlds 
leading rental car consolidators. The companys ˜direct connect technology allows customers to search hundreds of 
suppliers and book their rental car in just three clicks. Currently 550 of the worlds most trusted car hire companies 
ArgusCarHire.com Retracts Press Release Regarding Association between ArgusCarHire.com and Ryanair
subscribe to the system, providing Argus Customers with the lowest all-inclusive pricing in 22 languages at 25,000 
locations worldwide including airports, train stations ferry ports and city centres in 134 countries worldwide.
###
For the original version on PRWeb visit: http://www.prweb.com/releases/prwebcar-hire/ryanair/prweb4917324.htm

 The Travel Observatory: The Explosion of Low Cost Airlines
Paris, Ile de France -- (           SBWIRE) -- 12/21/2010 --  In the last ten years low cost airline companies have 
completely turned our travel habits inside out. liligo.com has integrated these 70 companies into their flight search 
engine. Today, however, not all travellers are equal when faced with a œlow cost offer.
 Stacking up low cost airlines

 2-Easyjet 1659

 5-Flybe 660
 6-Wizz Air 530

 11-Condor 242
 12-Jetairfly 201
 13-Air Asia 171
 14-FlyNiki 166
 15-Transavia 165
 TOP 10 airlines departing from the UK (Number of clicks)

 5-Thomson Airways
 6-Bmibaby

 10-Germanwings
 Stacking up countries: Italy leads in low cost service
 TOP 5 countries serving the most cities with low cost flights
 1-Italy
 2-Spain
 3-Germany 
 4-France
 5-United Kingdom
 Italy is at the head of the pack with more than 2300 routes available. Thats 50% more destination cities than the 
UK.
 UK cities do not offer equal low cost service

Credit Suisse ( NYSE : CS ) Analysts Downgrade Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ : RYAAY ) to œNeutral
Credit Suisse (NYSE: CS) Analysts Downgrade Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ: RYAAY) to œNeutral
American Consumer News
December 17, 2010 Friday 4:57 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 American Consumer News
Length: 267 words
Byline: admin
Body
   Dec. 17, 2010 (American Consumer News delivered by Newstex) --
Credit Suisse (NYSE: CS) research analysts downgraded Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ: RYAAY) from an 
œoutperform rating to a œneutral rating in a research note issued to investors on Tuesday.
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ: RYAAY)s stock traded down 0.53% on Friday, hitting $29.75. Ryanair Holdings plc 
(OOTC:RYAOF)  has a 52 week range of $21.55 to $33.38. The stocks 50-day moving average is $30.73 and its 
200-day moving average is $29.75. Analysts predict on average that Ryanair Holdings plc will post $-0.34 earnings 
per share next quarter. The company has a market cap of $N/A and a P/E (price-to-earnings ratio) of N/A.
About Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ: RYAAY)
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is the holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates a 
low-fares, scheduled passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, Continental Europe and Morocco. At June 30, 2010, with its operating fleet of 250 Boeing (NYSE:BA)  
737-800 aircraft, Ryanair offered approximately 1,300 scheduled short-haul flights per day serving 155 airports 
throughout Europe and Morocco, and flying approximately 1,100 routes. The Company also holds a 29.8% interest 
in Aer Lingus Group plc (OOTC:AELGF)  (Aer Lingus). During the Fiscal year ended March 31, 2010 (fiscal 2010), 
Ryanair announced 356 new routes originating from Belgium, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Lithuania, Malta, 
Norway, Portugal, Slovakia, Spain, Sweden and the United Kingdom.
 Newstex ID: AMCN-5684-51789693  
Notes

Top Companies in the Irish Transportation and Logistics Industry: IT Spending Predictor 2010 “ new report 
released
Top Companies in the Irish Transportation and Logistics Industry: IT 
Spending Predictor 2010 “ new report released
CompaniesandMarkets.com
December 16, 2010 Thursday 2:30 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 CompaniesandMarkets.com
Length: 282 words
Body
   Dec. 16, 2010 (CompaniesandMarkets.com delivered by Newstex) -- 
 This databook provides estimates of IT spending for the top companies in the Irish Transportation and Logistics 
industry. The databook is a comprehensive source of IT spending by company, including assessment by technology 
and channel.
Scope
*Our view of the top companies in the Irish Transportation and Logistics sector in terms of IT spending
*A breakdown of the estimated IT budget by technology for each of the top companies
*A breakdown of the estimated IT budget by channel for each of the top companies
Highlights
The top companies in the Irish transportation and logistics industry in terms of estimated IT spending spent the 
largest portion of their IT budgets on services, a segment that accounted for about 27% of the IT budgets among 
these firms. This was followed by spending on software and hardware.
Among the top companies, a major portion of IT spending is allocated to internal IT. Internal IT alone accounted for 
approximately 27% of the total estimated IT spending by these companies. Ryanair Holdings plc (OOTC:RYAOF)  
(NASDAQ:RYAAY)  remained the leading company in terms of spending on the various channels, followed by Aer 
Lingus Group plc (OOTC:AELGF)  and An Post.
Reasons to Purchase

released
*Gain insight into IT budget breakdown of top companies in the Irish Transportation and Logistics industry and 
identify notable areas of allocation
*Identify organizations with top IT expenditures in your target markets
*Leverage IT spending pattern information to tailor account targeting based on company demographics

Newstex Web Blogs
