Length: 296 words
Body
   Dec. 14, 2010 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, December 14th (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index is trading higher at $47.58, which 
represents 0.06% versus its previous close. The airline index is mixed with 7 out of 12 airlines trading higher.
US Airways (NYSE:LCC) is the top performer of the sector so far, trading at $10.66 representing 1.43%. versus the 
previous trading session. Shares of US Airways, the Phoenix based airline have defined support at $10.39 and 
resistance at $11.98.
SkyWest (NASDAQ:SKYW) is also among the top performers, currently trading at $16.48 representing 1.29% from 
its previous close. SkyWest, the regional airline servicing major airlines like Delta (NYSE:DAL)  and United has 
calculated support and resistance levels at $15.38 and $16.82 respectively. The other top performer is Southwest 
Airlines Co. (NYSE:LUV), which is trading at $12.95 representing 0.86% from the previous trading session.
The sector's worst performers include Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes (NYSE:GOL) that is trading at $14.98 or -
2.6% from the previous close. Shares of Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes, the low fare Brazilian domestic airline have 
defined support at $15.27 and resistance at $17.19. Also among the worst performers is Ryanair 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY), which is currently trading at $30.25 representing -0.98% from the previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for January delivery is trading higher trading at $88.69 a barrel on the New York Mercantile 
Exchange higher by $0.08 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by traders as they 
usually correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is covered by the 
price of fuel.

Don't piss off Ryanair : Disgruntled pilot transferred to Lithuania
Don't piss off Ryanair: Disgruntled pilot transferred to Lithuania
Gadling
December 8, 2010 Wednesday 3:00 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 Gadling
Length: 256 words
Byline: McLean Robbins
Body
   Dec. 8, 2010 (AOL Weblogs delivered by Newstex) -- 
 Thanks to OnlineTravelReview for this gem: A            Ryanairpilot has quit after being transferred to Lithuania, 
allegedly in response to his remarks against CEO Michael O'Leary in the            Financial Timesnewspaper.
Captain Morgan Fischer, a five year RyanAir pilot with more than 20 years of experience, is the first senior staff 
member to comment publicly against his employer. He wrote a letter in response to CEO O'Leary's suggestion that 
a 737 aircraft only needs on pilot and a "trained flight attendant" to jump in in the case of emergency. Fischer, who 
is no longer with the company, is quoted in FT as saying:
 "I would propose that Ryanair replace the CEO with a probationary cabin crew member currently earning 
approximately ??13,200 net per annum," Capt Fischer has written in a letter to the Financial Times, which reported 
Mr O'Leary's comments last week.
 "Ryanair would benefit by saving millions of euros in salary, benefits and stock options," the captain said, and there 
would be no need for approval from the authorities.
Fischer, an American, was recently transfarred from his base in Marseilles, France to Kaunas, Lithuania after his 
based closed. Cooincidence? We're not sure. But Fischer believes it's more than just bad luck - other pilots were 
offered spots in Spain, France and Italy, he says. Fischer has since quit.
That will teach you not to argue publicly with your employer. Or not.
[Image via Flickr user Mielko]
 Newstex ID: AOLB-5155-51495189

Ryanair insanity: Captain Morgan suggests mutiny, ordered to Lithuania
Ryanair insanity: Captain Morgan suggests mutiny, ordered to Lithuania
Gadling
December 7, 2010 Tuesday 1:30 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 Gadling
Length: 275 words
Byline: Tom Johansmeyer
Body
   Dec. 7, 2010 (AOL Weblogs delivered by Newstex) -- 
 If I could make this stuff up, I'd become a novelist. Seriously.
Captain Morgan Fischer, a pilot with Ryanair, decided to try out the type of stunt for which his boss,            Michael 
O'Leary, is famous. And, he learned what happens when you tangle with a master media whore.
Apparently implying that O'Leary is a moron, Fischer took public issue with the company CEO's notion that a co-
pilot could be swapped out with a flight attendant. So, he suggested that O'Leary be replaced with someone from 
that pool of employees, specifically a "probationary cabin crew member currently earning ??13,200 a year."
I'm starting to believe that O'Leary is thin-skinned.
After taking a potshot at the Ryanair top dog, any hope Captain Morgan had of landing someplace warm was 
dashed. Rather,            according to the Guardian, he "was offered a transfer to Kaunas in            Lithuania after 
Ryanair announced the closure of operations in Marseille, where the pilot is based."
Keep in mind that Fischer, an American, is "embroiled in a contractual dispute with the airline and, according to 
Ryanair, did not submit a request for a reassignment destination." Unlike the other pilots in his situation, he won't be 
able to score a new spot in a place like Spain, Portugal or Italy.
There's a bit of extra significance here, because "Kaunas is considered Siberia for Ryanair pilots." That only leaves 
one question: is Ryanair considered Siberia for pilots at other            airlines
Gallery:            A Closer Look at Ryanair
[photo by            MarkScottAustinTX via Flickr]

Nudity in Calendars
Nudity in Calendars
Iain Dale's Diary
December 7, 2010 Tuesday 6:23 AM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 Iain Dale's Diary
Length: 223 words
Byline: Iain Dale
Body
   Dec. 7, 2010 (Iain Dale's Diary delivered by Newstex) -- 
           
Last night I interviewed Labour MEP Mary Honeyball about her criticism of Ryanair for producing a charity calendar 
full of scantily clad flight attendants. Depsite the fact that it is expected to raise £85,000 for charity, Ms Honeyball 
thinks it shouldn't have been produced on the basis that it objectifies women and Ryanair may have put pressure on 
its employees to take part - not that she had a shred of evidence for the accusation, mind you. She seems quite 
happy for men to appear semi naked in calendars which are on sale in shopping centres around the country. What's 
the difference? We had a great caller last night, Laura in Epsom, who, speaking as a feminist, said she thought it 
was great that women felt liberated enough to appear in calendars like this. In my view, if semi naked firemen with 
their bodies covered in oil can appear on a calendar sold in a normal retail outlet, I cannot for the life of me see how 
one can object to Ryanair flight attendants appearing in their bikinis.
Mary Honeyball has done some fantastic work on preventing human trafficking. I think she should stick to that as 
she's on far safer ground than the flimsy arguments she produces in her interview.
Click HERE to listen to the interview.

   Dec. 6, 2010 (CompaniesandMarkets.com delivered by Newstex) -- 
 This report is an 'on-demand' product. The report will be emailed within 2 business days of an order.
This SWOT Analysis & Company Profile for Ryanair Holdings plc (OOTC:RYAOF)  (NASDAQ:RYAAY)  contains a 
company overview, key facts, locations and subsidiaries, news and events as well as a SWOT analysis of the 
company.
This SWOT Analysis company profile is a crucial resource for industry executives and anyone looking to quickly 
understand the key information concerning Ryanair Holdings plc's business.
"Ryanair Holdings plc SWOT Analysis & Company Profile" reports utilize a wide range of primary and secondary 
sources, which are analyzed and presented in a consistent and easily accessible format. 
Our analysts strictly follow a standardized research methodology to ensure high levels of data quality and these 
characteristics guarantee a unique report.
Scope
¢ Examines and identifies key information and issues about (Ryanair Holdings plc) for business intelligence 
requirements
¢ Studies and presents Ryanair Holdings plc's strengths, weaknesses, opportunities (growth potential) and threats 
(competition). Strategic and operational business information is objectively reported.
¢ The profile contains business operations, the company history, major products and services, prospects, key 
competitors, structure and key employees, locations and subsidiaries.
Reasons To Buy
¢ Quickly enhance your understanding of the company.
Ryanair Holdings plc : SWOT Analysis & Company Profile “ new report released
¢ Obtain details and analysis of the market and competitors as well as internal and external factors which could 
impact the industry.
¢ Increase business/sales activities by understanding your competitors' businesses better.
¢ Recognize potential partnerships and suppliers. 
¢ Obtain yearly profitability figures
Key Highlights
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair) is an Ireland based low-cost scheduled passenger airline, flying to destinations 
across Ireland, UK, Continental Europe and Morocco. It operates with 32 bases and flying in over 800 low fare 
routes across 26 countries, connecting nearly 148 destinations. Ryanair fleet consists of 196 Boeing (NYSE:BA)  
737-800 aircraft with a seating capacity of 189 seats. It also operates about 1,100 scheduled short-haul flights per 
day serving 147 locations throughout Europe and Morocco. In addition, it provides short-haul flights to 26 locations 
in the UK and Ireland. Complimenting its airlines services, it also offers host of related services including car rental 
services, hostels, and co-branded credit cards, among others. Ryanair is headquartered at Dublin, Ireland.

Taking the Kids to London
Taking the Kids to London
New Media Travel
December 5, 2010 Sunday 2:30 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 New Media Travel
Length: 365 words
Byline: travelvideopostcard
Body
   Dec. 5, 2010 (New Media Travel delivered by Newstex) --
How to Take The Kids to London
Kaleel Sakakeeny
London is a perfect family travel destination, and Just because you have kids doesnt mean you cant all go.
And the ratio of the pound to the dollar is improving.
A rebounding greenback will mean destinations that were off-limits to you last year are now accessible.
œThe strength of the dollar against the British pound means that this is a good time to take that trip to London, says 
Tom Hall, a travel editor for Lonely Planet in London.
By using value rail services like Eurostar or low-budget airlines like Ryanair and EasyJet, you can have a 
surprisingly affordable European vacation.
And Family Travel to London is ideal, because the city with its close cultural and historical ties is a terrific 
destination for families having their first overseas adventure.
The iconic attractions like the Double-decker bus and the famous London Bobby are familiar and comforting, and 
Londons underground system (TheTube) is easy for families to understand.
And that makes traveling through London fun, easy cultural experience.
Taking the Kids to London
Although London is a relatively simple family travel destination, family travel anywhere is a challenge.
Here are some simple but important  tips:
¢ Be sure to schedule free time. A day in the park people watching or having a picnic can beat any tourist attraction
¢ Let the kids carry their own money, and give them the experience of converting dollars to pounds. Its a great math 
assignment and builds confidence and self-esteem
¢ Split up! Mom and dad can go in separate directions, each with a child, and come together to share later. Kids 
love having experiences their siblings dont
Youll be surprised how many traveling families never think of this or are uncomfortable trying it
It works.
¢ Avoid hotels. Consider renting a short-term apartment or œflat. Youll save money on meals and œlive like a 
native shopping the local shops.
And youll meet people more quickly, and travel is always about connecting with people, not necessarily seeing 
places!
Let us know how you do, and watch the Taking Your Kids to London Family Travel Video PostCard

Self Weighing Luggage launched to aid Business Travellers in 2011
Self Weighing Luggage launched to aid Business Travellers in 2011
American Consumer News
December 2, 2010 Thursday 12:10 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 American Consumer News
Length: 626 words
Byline: admin
Body
   Dec. 2, 2010 (American Consumer News delivered by Newstex) --
 Self Weighing Luggage launched to aid Business Travellers in 2011
The current weather conditions at Gatwick and other UK Airports are playing havoc with UK businesses travellers. 
Coming at a time when the the green shoots of recovery are appearing in the economy this is an unwanted blow. 
The recent recession has had many businesses and business travellers looking at costs and trying where possible 
to reduce their expenditure. For many, 2011 will see a return to the skies, but perhaps in a more cost-effective 
manner. Cost will be a driving force and the launch of self weighing luggage from FLYLIGHTLuggage.co.uk can 
help make the excess baggage charge history.
 (PRWeb UK) December 2, 2010
 The current weather conditions at Gatwick and other UK Airports are playing havoc with UK businesses travellers. 
Coming at a time when the the green shoots of receovery are appearing in the economy this is an unwanted blow.
The recent recession has had many businesses and business travellers looking at costs and trying where possible 
to reduce their expenditure. Delays and cancellations caused by weather, ash cloud or indeed industrial dispute 
have impacted on business travel budgets. For many this meant reducing air travel, however as the economy 
improves the imperative to get out and meet clients grows as well. While costs due to weather, strikes or volcanos 
are outside the control of the business traveller, some cost can be curtailed. Business travel in 2011 will see a 
return to the skies, but perhaps in a more cost-effective manner. Cost will be a driving force and most will be keen 
to avoid the scourge of the modern flyer “ the excess baggage charge.
Incidental revenues earned from excess baggage charges have been one of the key drivers of profits for airlines 
such as Ryanair and Easyjet, whilst even the traditional airlines such as BA earn revenue from such charges.
Self Weighing Luggage launched to aid Business Travellers in 2011
Packing for a business trip requires forethought and planning but on a trip where the itinerary has not been 
confirmed those extra pairs of shoes and clothing, not too mention, laptops, brochures or samples tossed into the 
suitcase at the last minute could just be enough to tip the baggage over the weight limit. This is where the airlines 
can add charges to the unsuspecting traveller. It many cases this can be many times the amount actually paid for 
the flight.
Although low budget airlines offer unbelievable great deals on air fares, these prices will rise substantially when 
luggage reaches the wrong end of the scales. With self weighing luggage such as FlyLight Luggage, business 
travellers can avoid inflated excess baggage fees with luggage with built in scales, making sure that weight limits 
are easily adhered to.
Indeed it was on a Ryanair flight from Shannon that, Flylight Luggage was born on the idea to innovate a core 
consumer product, incorporating an integral self weighing luggage device that fulfills the size dimensions of most 
airlines.
The recently launched self weighing luggage from FLYLIGHTLuggage.co.uk has been built with business travellers 
in mind and will save money, time and inconvenience. The clever digital display screen is battery operated (new 
batteries supplied) and is incorporated in the handle mechanism.
Flylight Luggage is the sole distributor in the UK for these cases; sets can be ordered on line by visiting the Flylight 
Luggage online store.
Deliveries take 3 to 5 days; all technical questions are answered on the website but there is also a helpline for any 
queries +44 (0) 1202 769 570.
###
For the original version on PRWeb visit: http://www.prweb.com/releases/prwebself-weighing-luggage/Dec786-
flylight-luggage/prweb4840724.htm
 Newstex ID: AMCN-5684-51314695

Delta - Worst Performing Airline - Mid-Day Update
Delta - Worst Performing Airline - Mid-Day Update
TradersHuddle.com
December 2, 2010 Thursday 2:10 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 TradersHuddle.com
Length: 278 words
Body
   Dec. 2, 2010 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, December 2nd (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index is trading lower at $49.51, which 
represents -0.32% versus its previous close. The airline index is exhibiting weakness throughout with 4 out of 12 
airlines trading higher.
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) is the top performer of the sector so far, trading at $31.44 representing 1.7%. versus 
the previous trading session. Shares of Ryanair, the low fare European airline have defined support at $28.80 and 
resistance at $30.73.
Lan Airlines (NYSE:LFL) is also among the top performers, currently trading at $31.51 representing 1.16% from its 
previous close. Lan Airlines, the Chilean based airline has calculated support and resistance levels at $29.70 and 
$31.62 respectively. The other top performer is Tam (NYSE:TAM), which is trading at $25.35 representing 1.08% 
from the previous trading session.
The sector's worst performers include Delta (NYSE:DAL) that is trading at $13.6 or -2.02% from the previous close. 
Shares of Delta, the largest airline in the world have defined support at $12.87 and resistance at $14.38. Also 
among the worst performers is AMR (NYSE:AMR), which is currently trading at $8.46 representing -1.97% from the 
previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for December delivery is trading lower trading at $81.51 a barrel on the New York Mercantile 
Exchange lower by $-0.25 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by traders as they 
usually correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is covered by the 
price of fuel.

The Case For Betting Against The Airlines (LUV, AAI, UAL , DAL , LCCALKJBLURYAAY, FAA, AMR , SKYW)
The Case For Betting Against The Airlines (LUV, AAI, UAL, DAL, 
LCCALKJBLURYAAY, FAA, AMR, SKYW)
The Business Insider
December 2, 2010 Thursday 5:09 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 The Business Insider
Length: 1463 words
Byline: Robert Goldsborough
Body
   Dec. 2, 2010 (The Business Insider delivered by Newstex) --
For investors in most airline companies, 2010 has been a terrific  year. Most air carriers' stock prices soared in 
2010--a marked departure  from the previous several years of pain from a weak economy, excess  capacity, and oil 
price increases that in 2008 made fuel expenses their  highest percentage of airline operating costs ever.
Driving this  outperformance have been both fundamental and non-fundamental factors.  The industry has emerged 
from the recession healthy, with passenger  volumes rising nicely on effectively flat ticket prices and the  carriers' 
non-fuel costs down or growing modestly at best. In addition,  stock prices have been buffeted by a wave of 
consolidation that has  begun taking place;  Southwest Airlines (NYSE:LUV)   (NYSE:LUV - News) recently 
announced that it will acquire fellow low-cost carrier  AirTran Holdings (NYSE:AAI)   (NYSE:AAI - News),  and 
United Airlines owner UAL Corporation recently merged with  Continental Airlines to form  United Continental 
Holdings (NYSE:UAL)   (NYSE:UAL - News), the largest airline company in the world. These deals have come on 
the heels of  Delta Air Lines (NYSE:DAL)   (NYSE:DAL - News)  acquiring Northwest Airlines in 2008, and they 
have helped underscore  the fact that the entire airline industry seems to be embracing capacity  discipline and is 
focusing on cost containment. In addition, investors  ostensibly are pricing acquisition premiums into some of the 
remaining  names in the space.
Explosive Stock-Price Returns
Holders of  almost all airline companies have been rewarded nicely in 2010. United  Continental, for instance, was 
up 125% in the first 10 months of 2010,  while  US Airways (NYSE:LCC)   (NYSE:LCC - News) rose 144%,  Alaska 
Air Group (NYSE:ALK)   (NYSE:ALK - News)  increased 53%, and AirTran, buoyed by its purchase offer by 
Southwest,  rose 42%. Other players also have registered nice gains, including   JetBlue Airways (NASDAQ:JBLU)   
The Case For Betting Against The Airlines (LUV, AAI, UAL , DAL , LCCALKJBLURYAAY, FAA, AMR , SKYW)
(NasdaqGS:JBLU - News)(up 28%), Delta (up 22%),  Ryanair Holdings  (NasdaqGS:RYAAY - News)(up 22%), and 
Southwest (up 20%).
Traditional  open-end mutual funds have modest exposure at best to the airline  industry; for example, last month, 
Morningstar's Fund Spy column noted  that no one mutual fund as of Oct. 7 had invested more than 14.5% of its  
assets in airlines. Instead, we believe that the best way to gain  exposure to the entire airline industry while avoiding 
single-stock risk  is through an exchange-traded fund. In addition, we highlight that the  ETF structure offers some 
flexibility for investors that traditional  mutual funds do not offer, including the ability to short an ETF that an  
investor believes is overvalued.
Investing in an Airline ETF
Right now, investors can consider just one airline ETF,  Guggenheim Airline  (NYSEArca:FAA - News),  which 
began trading in early 2009 and which has nearly doubled in price  since that time. A concentrated ETF that holds 
just 23 airline  companies, Guggenheim Airline is a modified equal-dollar-weighted fund,  with large allocations 
devoted to United Continental (almost 19% of  assets), and Delta and Southwest (each of which comprises another 
15% or  so of assets). Just over 75% of assets are invested in U.S. airlines;  other U.S.-listed companies that FAA 
holds include US Airways, JetBlue,   AMR Corporation (NYSE:AMR)   (NYSE:AMR - News), SkyWest  
(NasdaqGS:SKYW - News), Alaska Air Group, and Ryanair Holdings.
Given  current industry fundamentals and FAA's high valuation, we believe that  this ETF would make a compelling 
short opportunity for an investor.
First,  there is no question that investors in the airline industry need a  strong stomach. There have been more than 
180 bankruptcies in the  industry over the past 30 years, and since deregulation in the late  1970s, the industry has 
been plagued by issues like capital intensity,  minimal customer-switching costs, and cutthroat competition. In more  
recent years, oil-price volatility has only exacerbated the industry's  structural issues. Indeed, famed investor 
Warren Buffett purchased  preferred shares in US Airways (then known as USAir) in the early 1990s  and later rode 
the company into bankruptcy before recovering and booking  a small profit; Buffett has lamented that investment, 
calling it his  worst one ever. He also has noted that in the airline industry, "you've  got huge fixed costs, you've got 
strong labor unions and you've got  commodity pricing. That is not a great recipe for success." And while,  as we 
noted above, we are encouraged by better and more rational  behavior on the part of the airlines in the form of 
capacity discipline  and cost containment, the industry has to overcome a long track record  to the contrary. On top 
of this, recently rising fuel costs have not yet  begun to affect airlines' earnings results but undoubtedly will in  
coming quarters, quite possibly to a level greater than the carriers are  suggesting in their guidance.
In addition, the valuation of air  carriers is very high, in our opinion, and bound to revert to the mean,  given that 
merger premiums appear to be baked into many companies' share  prices. Although further consolidation 
unquestionably is ahead, we do  not believe that all carriers will be acquired away, meaning that share  prices are 
likely to fall back down to earth. Also, of the nine  U.S-listed companies in this fund that Morningstar's equity 
analysts  follow (comprising almost 69% of the assets of this ETF), just  two--United Continental and AMR--trade at 
any meaningful discount to our  analysts' fair value estimates. The other seven all trade at or above  our analysts' 
fair value estimates. In addition, Morningstar's equity  analysts assign uncertainty ratings of "very high" to five of 
these nine  companies, and "extreme" uncertainty ratings to the other four: Delta,  American, US Airways, and 
United. We believe those factors make an ETF  that is ripe to be shorted.
FAA charges an annual expense ratio of  0.65%, which may seem high. However, this ETF holds airline stocks  
traded on exchanges all around the world, and it would be very costly  for investors to try to assemble this same 
portfolio of companies on  their own. We also would alert investors that this ETF is not very  liquid, meaning that 
investors should keep a close eye on bid-ask  spreads when transacting. That said, individual investors using limit  
orders for FAA probably won't run into any liquidity issues. And, we'd  also note that taking an outright short position 
The Case For Betting Against The Airlines (LUV, AAI, UAL , DAL , LCCALKJBLURYAAY, FAA, AMR , SKYW)
in a security,  including an ETF, can expose investors to the unlimited loss potential  if the ETF continues to rise. In 
addition, the expense ratio actually  serves as a slight tailwind for the investor who is short.
Few Other ETF Options 
Right  now, FAA is the lone ETF with any meaningful exposure whatsoever to the  airline industry. Other ETFs in 
which airline companies are included  make fairly ineffective options for an investor who is searching for  airline 
exposure. For example, five airline companies are included in  the shipper-intense  iShares Dow Jones 
Transportation Average   (NYSEArca:IYT - News)  (0.47% expense ratio), which has the next-largest airline  
representation of any U.S. ETF. However, even in IYT, the air carriers  have fairly small position sizes (together 
comprising less than 8.6% of  the ETF's assets), and the performance of IYT and FAA hasn't been  particularly 
correlated historically. After IYT, the representation by  airline companies in U.S. ETFs drops precipitously. If 
anything, the  best alternative is probably to buy single stocks of airlines, despite  the risk that single-stock investing 
presents.
Note that ETF  providers are known for chasing returns, with good-performing sectors  typically having several 
product launches while they're hot. However,  until recently, aviation has not had a prolonged period of strong  
returns while ETFs have been growing. So we would not be at all  surprised to see other ETF providers launch 
niche aviation-themed ETFs  in the future.
Robert Goldsborough does not own shares in any of the securities mentioned above.

award-winning portfolio tools. Learn More.

Ryanair Moving Above Resistance
Ryanair Moving Above Resistance
TradersHuddle.com
December 2, 2010 Thursday 10:04 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 TradersHuddle.com
Length: 167 words
Body
   Dec. 2, 2010 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
New York, December 2nd (TradersHuddle.com) - Shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (OOTC:RYAOF)  
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) closed the trading session at $31.51 just above calculated resistance at $30.73 moving to what 
appears to be a new range, as this move will clearly raise the attention of momentum buyers.
Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) provides low fare passenger airline services to destinations in Europe.
Ryanair's stock was trading in a well defined range with support at $28.80 and resistance at $30.73, given that this 
range was broken traders will be closely monitoring the stock?s price action for clues of direction.
From a technical perspective it can be expected that previous resistance becomes support, as the new range gets 
defined, however, given that Ryanair's stock is still near the broken resistance level, traders will be focusing on 
$30.73 to see if the stock holds the breakout without rolling over.

A Word To The Unwise
A Word To The Unwise
The Magistrate's Blog
November 30, 2010 Tuesday 1:26 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 The Magistrate's Blog
Length: 405 words
Byline: Bystander
Body
   Nov. 30, 2010 (The Magistrate's Blog delivered by Newstex) -- 
 This blog is blessed with a following of people who read, comment, agree, disagree, query, quibble, and whatnot. 
Apart from my loyal following of Mr. Toad and his acolytes (who maintain silence unless I venture to suggest that 
some drivers treat the law too casually for my taste) I don't imagine that I have too many avid readers from the 
criminal fraternity.
So here, as an early Christmas present, are a few of Uncle Bystander's hard-learned insights into the sharp end of 
criminal justice:-
i) A life of crime is rubbish, even if you are good at it.
ii) It's no fun having a stash of gold bars buried under the patio if you lie awake nights wondering when Harry The 
Hatchet or (preferably) the Old Bill come crashing through the door to exact their particular kind of retribution.
iii) Most drug dealers live with their Mum and don't earn enough to fund their own habit. The blinged-up Merc-
driving Mr. Big is largely a media myth. It's a dirty shifty business.
iv) Never trust your Co-D. 'Honour Among Thieves' is bollocks. You think he's your mate but after he has sold you 
down the river he will rob his Granny's purse.
v) Listen to your brief. He is smarter and better educated than you. He is very likely free, as well. If he tells you to 
plead, plead. If he tells you it's worth a run, go for it but don't forget the one-third off that you are gambling with. In 
court, shut up. Let him do the talking, you can do the time. Win or lose he goes home to his wife and kids.
vi) However much you hear about rubbish Government computers, don't forget that even the piss-poor ones have a 
really long memory. If you have had a result in avoiding capture for some piece of naughtiness, but the police have 
your DNA or prints or whatever - forget about that Ryanair cheapie with Angie-Leigh or Kayley. The airport 
computer will sort out a reception committee for you before you have left Kos.
vii) Think carefully before you elect for the Crown Court. A jury is easier to fool than a bench of JPs (who are, trust 
me, rarely as daft as they look) but if you come unstuck and you get the wrong judge you will get hammered. I sat 
next to one of the old school once as he sentenced a mugger. Even on a late plea, Hizonner weighed the man off 
for a nine, when the unofficial estimates were for five at worst.
Good luck, but don't push your luck.  
A Word To The Unwise
 Newstex ID: MGST-5501-51251117  
Notes

Airline Stocks Mid-Day Round Up - Lower: RYAAY, AMR, GOL
TradersHuddle.com
November 30, 2010 Tuesday 2:10 PM EST

Length: 292 words
Body
   Nov. 30, 2010 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, November 30th (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index is trading lower at $48.61, which 
represents -1.39% versus its previous close. The airline index is seeing a broad decline with 1 out of 12 airlines 
trading higher.
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) is the top performer of the sector so far, trading at $30.47 representing -0.07%. versus 
the previous trading session. Shares of Ryanair, the low fare European airline have defined support at $28.80 and 
resistance at $30.73.
AMR (NYSE:AMR) is also among the top performers, currently trading at $8.45 representing -0.35% from its 
previous close. AMR, the owner and operator of the 2nd largest U.S. based airline and founder member of the 
Oneworld airline alliance has calculated support and resistance levels at $7.96 and $8.98 respectively. The other 
top performer is Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes (NYSE:GOL), which is trading at $15.99 representing -1.05% from 
the previous trading session.
The sector's worst performers include Tam (NYSE:TAM) that is trading at $24.12 or -3.25% from the previous 
close. Shares of Tam, the Brazil based airline have defined support at $23.69 and resistance at $25.78. Also 
among the worst performers is Delta (NYSE:DAL), which is currently trading at $13.81 representing -2.44% from 
the previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for December delivery is trading lower trading at $81.51 a barrel on the New York Mercantile 
Exchange lower by $-0.25 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by traders as they 
usually correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is covered by the 
price of fuel.

Notes
The views expressed on blogs distributed by Newstex and its re-distributors ("Blogs on Demand®") are solely the 
author's and not necessarily the views of Newstex or its re-distributors. Posts from such authors are provided "AS 
IS", with no warranties, and confer no rights. The material and information provided in Blogs on Demand® are for 
general information only and should not, in any respect, be relied on as professional advice. No content on such 
Blogs on Demand® is "read and approved" before it is posted. Accordingly, neither Newstex nor its re-distributors

PLC (OOTC:RYAOF)  (NASDAQ:RYAAY), early in the trading session. Ryanair is currently trading higher by

Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) provides low fare passenger airline services to destinations in Europe.
Ryanair has already traded 0.842 times its 3-month average volume, and has calculated support and resistance at 
$28.80 and $30.73 respectively. Traders like to use volume as their lie detector for price action moves through 
predefined trading ranges.
The overall market index S&P 500 is trading lower by -0.63% from its previous trading close, which means that 
Ryanair stock is outperforming the overall market.

Body
   Nov. 29, 2010 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, November 29th (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index is trading lower at $48.84, which 
represents -1.87% versus its previous close. The airline index is seeing a broad decline with 1 out of 12 airlines 
trading higher.
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) is the top performer of the sector so far, trading at $30.32 representing -0.52%. versus 
the previous trading session. Shares of Ryanair, the low fare European airline have defined support at $28.80 and 
resistance at $30.73.
SkyWest (NASDAQ:SKYW) is also among the top performers, currently trading at $16.07 representing -0.62% from 
its previous close. SkyWest, the regional airline servicing major airlines like Delta (NYSE:DAL)  and United has 
calculated support and resistance levels at $15.38 and $16.19 respectively. The other top performer is Southwest 
Airlines Co. (NYSE:LUV), which is trading at $13.37 representing -1.18% from the previous trading session.
The sector's worst performers include US Airways (NYSE:LCC) that is trading at $11.24 or -3.93% from the 
previous close. Shares of US Airways, the Phoenix based airline have defined support at $10.51 and resistance at 
$11.21. Also among the worst performers is Tam (NYSE:TAM), which is currently trading at $24.46 representing -
3.28% from the previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for December delivery is trading lower trading at $81.51 a barrel on the New York Mercantile 
Exchange lower by $-0.25 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by traders as they 
usually correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is covered by the 
price of fuel.

British Royal Etiquette: Dos and Donts of Advertising and Promotion
British Royal Etiquette: Dos and Donts of Advertising and Promotion
Consumer Advertising Law Blog
November 24, 2010 Wednesday 12:30 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 Consumer Advertising Law Blog
Length: 613 words
Byline: randal shaheen
Body
   Nov. 24, 2010 (Consumer Advertising Law Blog delivered by Newstex) --
The announcement of the            Royal engagement of Prince William to Kate Middleton is a cause for celebration 
in the UK. As advertisers, retailers, and the British Government eye up the opportunities for related advertising, 
merchandising, and tourism, it is the perfect opportunity to explore and refresh our knowledge on the rules and 
etiquette in the UK regarding advertising and promotion of the Royal Family and Royal events.
By and large, etiquette in the UK dictates that members of the Royal Family should not be used in any form of 
marketing communication or advertising which suggests their affiliation with or endorsement of a particular product 
and service. The UKs Advertising Standards Agency (ASA) CAP Code of advertising practice endorses this view, 
advising that members of the Royal Family should not be shown or mentioned in marketing communications without 
their prior permission (rule 6.2).  Incidental references to Royal Family members which are unconnected to the 
advertised product, or are merely a reference to a book, film, or article about the individual, may be acceptable. It 
remains to be seen whether the ASA will take any action in respect of Irish budget airline company Ryanair, which 
has already used a picture of the newly engaged couple to promote their low air fares
Rule 3.52 of the CAP Code advises that Royal Arms or Emblems should not be used by marketers without prior 
permission of the Lord Chamberlain, the senior official in the Royal Household. Conventional representations of the 
Royal Arms are as follows:
Section 99 of the UK Trade Mark Act 1994 takes a stronger view, making use of the Royal Arms or Emblems (or 
arms or emblems so closely resembling the Royal Arms that they are likely or calculated to deceive) in connection 
with a business and without the authority of the Queen, a criminal offence
The            UK Trade Mark Act also prevents applications to register trade marks incorporating elements of Royalty, 
such as the Royal Arms, or signs or devices resembling the Royal Arms, representations of the Royal Crown or any 
British Royal Etiquette: Dos and Donts of Advertising and Promotion
Royal flag, representations or portraits of the Royal Family, names of the Royal Family or names and pictorial 
representations of Royal residences (e.g. Balmoral), unless prior consent has been given by or on behalf of the 
Queen. Applications to register marks incorporating the word ROYAL may also be opposed or rejected, particularly 
where the word is used in relation to high quality goods which might suggest Royal patronage, for example luxury or 
organic foods or high quality porcelain, or where the word is used alone or in conjunction with a descriptive word 
(e.g. ROYAL VENISON for meat). Marks of Royal Patronage, or Royal Warrants, may be applied to goods and 
services which have received formal endorsement by the Royal Family for their quality and excellence, but only by 
the particular Warrant Holder (individual or company) to whom the right has been granted.
So etiquette and law dictates that images or references to the Royal Family, or Royalty in general, should be used 
with extreme caution. However if Prince Williams engagement and Royal Wedding generates anything like the 
fervour created by that of his parents, the nations appetite for Royal memorabilia and commemorative 
merchandising will be considerable. If the estimated projections of the boost the Royal Wedding may have to the 
British economy are correct (£620 million has been suggested), marketers will likely want a slice of the royal pie, 
etiquette or not.
-            Richard Dickinson and Gemma Davies
 Newstex ID: CADL-7211-51069313  
Notes

Portugal Is Preparing For A One-Day All-Out National Strike
Portugal Is Preparing For A One-Day All-Out National Strike
The Business Insider
November 24, 2010 Wednesday 4:48 AM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 The Business Insider
Length: 475 words
Byline: Gavan Reilly
Body
   Nov. 24, 2010 (The Business Insider delivered by Newstex) --
PORTUGAL IS PREPARING for a day of            all-out national strike today, as part of a nationwide public protest 
against the countrys austerity budget which is set for approval in parliament on Friday.
The countrys two main trade unions, UGT and CGTP, are both holding a national day of industrial action “ the first 
time in 0ver two decades that the two unions have arranged co-ordinated protests “ and will involve workers from 
both the public and private sectors.
The two unions between them have over 1.5 million workers, and an overwhelming majority of them are expected to 
take part.
Opposition to the severe Budget is widespread, and its passage was only secured after the Social Democratic 
Party, the largest opposition party “ which had threatened to block its passage “            agreed to abstain on the 
vote.
Left Bloc leader Francisco Louca, who commands the fourth-biggest share of the Assembly of the Republic, has 
slammed the package, saying it would œpenalise families with tax increases and salary cuts.
Prime Minister Jose Socrates, however, has            pledged to remain in power and attempt to introduce the budget 
in efforts to avoid becoming the third Eurozone country “ after Greece and Ireland “ to require a bailout.
 Transport hit 
100% of staff on the Lisbon Metro system walked out of work at midnight, along with the entirety of the staff in many 
of the countrys city and town halls.
Portugal Is Preparing For A One-Day All-Out National Strike
Private businesses and transport have been massively affected;            the Wall Street Journal reports that the two 
largest main commuter lines into the countrys capital have also been shut down, while the majority of air travel into 
the country has also been hit.
           The Irish Independent reports that Ryanair has cancelled four flights to Faro airport “ two each from Dublin 
and Cork “ while Aer Lingus has cancelled its flight in both directions between Lisbon and Dublin.
Ryanair alone has been forced to pull 60 flights across its entire European operation as a result of the strikes, and 
claims that the industrial action is more disruptive to its operations than the volcanic ash cloud had proven earlier 
this year.
Portugals finances are under such strain that the archbishop of Braga has called on priests in his diocese to donate 
a months wages to those suffering hardest in the crisis.
œWe live in extremely serious times. We cannot ignore this and must show a concrete love for the people, 
Archbishop Jorge Ortega said in a letter to priests,            AFP reports.
The cost of borrowing for the Portuguese government            has this morning breached the 7% mark, for the first 
time since November 11.
------------
           This post previously appeared at TheJournal.ie
           Join the conversation about this story »

Ryanair passengers stage sit-down strike
Ryanair passengers stage sit-down strike
Gadling
November 17, 2010 Wednesday 2:30 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 Gadling
Length: 236 words
Byline: Sean McLachlan
Body
   Nov. 17, 2010 (AOL Weblogs delivered by Newstex) -- 
 What would travel bloggers do without Ryanair? From            trying to get rid of co-pilots to arresting passengers 
for            complaining about the sandwiches, the budget airline provides endless grist for our mill.
Yesterday more than a hundred passengers refused to leave their plane after their Ryanair flight from Fez, 
Morocco, to Beauvais, France, was diverted to Belgium. It was one of four Ryanair flights diverted to Liege due to 
foggy conditions in France. Passengers were offered a bus to their final destination, a journey of 225 miles. While 
passengers in three of the planes agreed to go, those in the fourth flight refused, insisting to be flown there instead. 
The flight had departed Fez three hours late and landed in Liege at 11:30 PM. The passengers didn't leave the 
plane until 3:30 in the morning to catch a 4:30 AM bus home.
That's the story both sides agree on. Beyond this, there are two stories. Passengers say they were then abandoned 
by the crew, who even left the cockpit open, and were not given any water for several hours. The toilets were also 
locked.
Ryanair said the crew stayed for an hour and only left when some passengers got disruptive. They also say that 
they would have gotten an earlier bus if they had agreed to leave.
[Photo courtesy user            Yap S S via Gadling's flickr pool]
 Newstex ID: AOLB-5155-50868951

Valuation Updates: Ryanair , Moog
Valuation Updates: Ryanair, Moog
FinancialWire
November 17, 2010 Wednesday 1:02 AM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 FinancialWire
Length: 499 words
Byline: Editor1
Body
   Nov. 17, 2010 (FinancialWire delivered by Newstex) --
November 17, 2010 (FinancialWire)(           http://www.financialwire.net/)(Investrend Research Syndicate) ” 
ValuEngine, Inc., has upgraded Ryanair Holdings plc (OOTC:RYAOF)  (NASDAQ:RYAAY)  (           RYAAY) and 
Moog, Inc. (NYSE:MOG A)  (           MOG.A)(           MOG.B) to a "5" rating, the services highest.
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, operates a low-fares scheduled passenger airline in Ireland. 
The company was founded in 1985 and is headquartered in Dublin, Ireland. Company summary analytics and an 
industry research report by ValuEngine on RYAAY is available via the Investrend Research Syndicate (at 
http://www.valuengine.com/rep/searchsrep?pid=42&srchfor=RYAAY).
Moog, Inc., designs, manufactures, and integrates precision motion and fluid controls, and control systems 
worldwide. The company was founded in 1951 and is headquartered in East Aurora, New York. Company summary 
analytics and an industry research report by ValuEngine on MOG is available via the Investrend Research 
Syndicate (at            http://www.valuengine.com/rep/searchsrep?pid=42&srchfor=MOG.A and            
http://www.valuengine.com/rep/searchsrep?pid=42&srchfor=MOG.B).
The ValuEngine Rating is an overall assessment of a stock's attractiveness. It combines the following five factors: 
ValuEngines proprietary valuation, risk-return tradeoff, momentum, market capitalization and ValuEngines 
proprietary forecasted one-month return.
Approximately 80 to 85 companies achieve this highest ValuEngine rating out of VEs total coverage of over 5,000 
publicly traded companies.
ValuEngine is a subscription-based business intelligence, market and equity analysis firm that provides exclusive, 
customized research and analysis solutions directly to companies, investors, investment banks and broker-dealers. 
Valuation Updates: Ryanair , Moog
A special arrangement between the Investrend Research Syndicate and ValuEngine provides for preferred 
introductions and complimentary value-added services for those enrolling into ValuEngine programs. For more 
information, including the option to arrange a preferred introduction to ValuEngine, go to ValuEngines dedicated 
Investrend Syndications webpage (at            http://www.investrend.com/valuengine).
The Investrend Research Syndicate (           http://www.investrend.com/research/syndicate), a proprietary entity of 
Investrend Communications, Inc., distributes equity research-related information issued by sources deemed to be

Crude Oil Lower - Airlines Higher: GOL, JBLU, RYAAY
Crude Oil Lower - Airlines Higher: GOL, JBLU, RYAAY
TradersHuddle.com
November 17, 2010 Wednesday 6:02 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 TradersHuddle.com
Length: 316 words
Body
   Nov. 17, 2010 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, November 17th (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index ended the session higher by closing at 
$47.57, which represents 0.37% versus its previous day close. The airline index exhibited strong upside with 10 out 
of 12 airlines trading higher.
Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes (NYSE:GOL) was the top performer of the sector today closing at $16.68 
representing 2.14%. versus the previous trading session. Shares of Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes, the low fare 
Brazilian domestic airline have defined support at $16.31 and resistance at $18.66.
JetBlue Airways (NASDAQ:JBLU) was also among the top performers, closed the trading session at $6.65 
representing 1.14% from its previous close. JetBlue Airways, the New York based discount airline has calculated 
support and resistance levels at $6.73 and $7.60 respectively. The other top performer was Ryanair 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY), which closed the trading session at $29.53 representing 1.13% from the previous trading 
session.
The sector's worst performers include Alaska Air (NYSE:ALK) that closed the trading session at $52.9 or -2.34% 
from the previous close. Shares of Alaska Air , the Airline serving destinations within the state of Alaska and the 
West Coast of the United States have defined support at $53.04 and resistance at $56.48. Also among the worst 
performers was AMR (NYSE:AMR), which closed the trading session at $8.03 representing -0.62% from the 
previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for December delivery was lower closing the trading session at $80.47 a barrel on the New York 
Mercantile Exchange lower by $-1.87 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by 
traders as they usually correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is 
covered by the price of fuel.
Crude Oil Lower - Airlines Higher: GOL, JBLU, RYAAY

Ryanair Crew Lock Toilets, Turn Off Lights And Leave Passengers On Plane For Four Hours
Ryanair Crew Lock Toilets, Turn Off Lights And Leave Passengers On Plane 
For Four Hours
The Business Insider
November 17, 2010 Wednesday 8:58 AM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 The Business Insider
Length: 113 words
Byline: Katya Wachtel
Body
   Nov. 17, 2010 (The Business Insider delivered by Newstex) --
A Ryanair crew locked more than 100 passengers on a plane in Belgium after they refused to get off the aircraft, the       
     Daily Mailreports.
The mostly French commuters were incensed that the plane, which was supposed to land near Paris, had been re-
routed to Liege in neighboring Belgium due to bad weather.
The crew offered for the stranded travelers to sit in a transit lounge inside the airport, but were rejected. So they 
locked the toilets, turned off the lights, and got off the plane.
For the full story, go to the Daily Mail
           Join the conversation about this story »

out of 12 airlines trading higher.

the previous trading session. Shares of Ryanair, the low fare European airline have defined support at $31.05 and 
resistance at $33.38.
Alaska Air (NYSE:ALK) was also among the top performers, closed the trading session at $53.88 representing 
0.34% from its previous close. Alaska Air , the Airline serving destinations within the state of Alaska and the West 
Coast of the United States has calculated support and resistance levels at $53.04 and $56.48 respectively. The 
other top performer was Tam (NYSE:TAM), which closed the trading session at $24.2 representing -0.08% from the 
previous trading session.

from the previous close. Shares of US Airways, the Phoenix based airline have defined support at $8.94 and 
resistance at $12.26. Also among the worst performers was SkyWest (NASDAQ:SKYW), which closed the trading 
session at $15.72 representing -1.69% from the previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for December delivery was flat closing the trading session at $0 a barrel on the New York 
Mercantile Exchange flat by $0 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by traders as 
they usually correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is covered by 
the price of fuel.

The individualist's dream
The individualist's dream
Gulliver
November 11, 2010 Thursday 12:50 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 Gulliver
Length: 508 words
Body
   Nov. 11, 2010 (The Economist delivered by Newstex) --
WHAT will the hotel of tomorrow look like? According to œ           Hotels 2020: Beyond Segmentation, a new report 
from Amadeus, a company that provides technology to the travel industry it will be a place where clever use of 
technology and social media allow the customer's desires to be met ever more effectively.
Indeed if I were a hotelier, the future outlined in the report would make me blanche. It predicts a growing cult of 
individualism among guests, who will increasingly expect their hotel experience to be configured precisely as they 
want it. Rohit Talwar, a futurist who wrote the report, talked to me about œthe emergence of an app culture, where 
consumers expect to have what they want when they want it.
As a result, hotels will have to be adaptable on several levels, not only to the range of macro-economic scenarios 
that could result from the fall-out to the financial crisis, but also to the particular needs of these newly individualist 
guests. As the report puts it:
A greater emphasis will be placed on offering a consumer led spectrum of choices from which guests can 
personalize their hotel stay “ encompassing everything from room size to linens, media and amenities.
Guests will not want to pay for the things they do not need. Mr Talwar questions whether they will still, for example, 
be prepared to pay for 400 television channels if they are only interested in a couple, or will be bringing their own 
entertainment and so just want a plug and Wi-Fi. And why should they be content with bog-standard hotel-chosen 
artwork on the walls when digital displays can show their own choice of photographs and pictures?
What kind of hotel will this rather spoilt new-age traveller be checking in to? Mr Talwar sees changes to hotel 
design happening in waves. So over the next two to three years hotels will be ripping out front desks, and guests 
will check in and out in their rooms or online. Then, with the next wave of technology, the vision becomes decidedly 
futuristic. Public spaces become invaded by technology, or specifically œvisual clutter, where guests sit watching 
The individualist's dream
3D holograms from their phones. And indeed, since customers wont want to sit down beside somebody watching a 
holographic movie on their computer, the best hotels will have to work out new ways to allow this technological elite 
to co-exist.
In an effort to pay for all this, hotels will increasingly try to maximise revenues from each customer. As Ryanair has 
realised, captive audiences are there to be sold to, and for hotels that might mean gadgets, branded goods, or more 
unusual items such as a œcity card that a guest can use to pay for items around the city. Hotel branding will change 
in other ways, of course. Where Giorgio Armani led the way in Dubai, others may follow. Indeed new entrants won't 
be restricted to the fashion world. The report poses the rather scary question: "Would there be customers for the 
Jumeirah Beckham Towers or the Hyatt Madonna?"
 Newstex ID: ECNM-5498-50822203  
Notes

TradersHuddle.com
November 11, 2010 Thursday 12:49 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 TradersHuddle.com
Length: 152 words
Body
   Nov. 11, 2010 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, November 11th (TradersHuddle.com) - Unusual high volume detected on shares of Ryanair Holdings 
PLC (OOTC:RYAOF)  (NASDAQ:RYAAY), early in the trading session. Ryanair is currently trading lower by 0.6%, 
so definitely the sellers in control, as the stock's volume is on pace to break its average.
Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) provides low fare passenger airline services to destinations in Europe.
Ryanair has already traded 0.778 times its 3-month average volume, and has calculated support and resistance at 
$31.05 and $33.38 respectively. Traders like to use volume as their lie detector for price action moves through 
predefined trading ranges.
The overall market index S&P 500 is trading lower by -0.85% from its previous trading close, which means that 
Ryanair stock is outperforming the overall market.

   Nov. 1, 2010 (Phil's Stock World delivered by Newstex) --
Courtesy of            Tyler Durden
  Asian stocks, emerging currencies, oil climb on China manufacturing, Korea data. Chinese factories get busy; 
Official PMI shows surprise gain, sends stocks higher. 
South Koreas inflation rate climbs to 20-month high, exports accelerate. US unemployment probably hovered near 
10% as Fed discusses additional easing. 3M is using acquisitions, its own labs to diversify into areas as biometrics 
and fuel cells. Ambak to file for bankruptcy if prepackaged plan is unsuccessful. Bancorp of New Jersey announces 
special $0.33 cash dividend. Chevron Q3 earnings fell 1.6% on weaker U.S. dollar and higher costs. Revs up 7.5%. 
China Citic Bank said Q3 profit increased 51% to $972M, on continued growth in lending. China Construction Banks 
Q3 net rises 31% to record $5.93B on higher lending. Colgate-Palmolive plans $438M debt offering. Cornings Sept. 
net income rises from $643M to $785M. Constellation Energy swings to Q3 loss on $2.5B in write downs to value of 
nuclear generation plant. DISH Network and Fox Networks reach comprehensive programming agreement. Enel 
raises about $3.1B in renewable energy initial share offering. ICBC paid $1 to acquire the Prime Dealer Srvcs unit 
of Fortis Securities from BNP Paribas. Lukoil plans to sell $800M of 10-year bonds at 6.25%. Mercks Q3 net 
dropped 90%, hurt by a $950M reserve booked for its pain drug Vioxx. Nomura slumps to 28-year low after profit 
tumbles 96% on overseas losses. Northeast Utilities raised 2010 EPS to $2.10-2.20 vs. $2.01 cons, up from $1.95-
2.05. Oracle seeks $2.3B in SAP ˜humiliation trial over downloaded code. Ryanair raises 2010 profit guidance to 
??380-400M, after Q3 net climbs 32%. TransDigm thats buying rival McKechnie Aerospace, is seeking $1.98B in 
bonds, loans. Weyerhaeuser posts Q2 net of $1.12B on ~$1B in income-tax adjustments. Revs up 20%. WPP 
joined peers in signalling a recovery in ad industry by saying that Q3 sales rose 12%.

Y.

Upgrades and Downgrades: Life Is Swell For Intel
Upgrades and Downgrades: Life Is Swell For Intel
Minyanville
November 1, 2010 Monday 9:35 AM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 Minyanville
Length: 887 words
Byline: Justin Sharon
Body
   Nov. 1, 2010 (Minyanville delivered by Newstex) -- 
 September, traditionally the single worst month in equities, saw the S&P 500 Index post its best such performance 
since 1939. October, which has had such historic market meltdowns as 1929 and 1987, was witness to a Dow gain 
of 3.06%, good for its best performance for four years. Since today starts what has invariably been the best three 
month period of the entire year for shares, contrarians have good reason to be concerned. A stock named Monster 
(MWW) appropriately enough paced the entire S&P 500 on the last session before Halloween, a 25.50% increase 
on Friday capping its best week since October of 08. Printer maker Lexmark International (LXK) experienced the 
scariest week, ending 19.0% lower after its top-line earnings came in light. On this particular Friday however 
commentators were careful to avoid the usual hyperbole of Wall Street, and no one was saying its stock            had 
bombed.
Two men in their mid fifties, Bill Gates and Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, both celebrated their birthdays on October 28th 
but the State Department remembered only one, even on the day Microsoft (MSFT) easily topped earnings 
estimates en route to rising 5.1% on the week. Pontiac            passed away on Sunday, as did another noteworthy 
octogenarian. Will both be sadly missed?            Ask not. And while China took ownership of the            worlds 
fastest supercomputer from America,            an 18 year old from these United States beat the Chinese on home soil 
to the Miss World crown, a reminder that for all the present economic attention over China, the rapidly aging country 
could very likely get old before it gets rich. Today in economics, Octobers ISM manufacturing index and September 
construction spending are each out at 10:00AM Eastern. Peak earnings season has passed but today still sees 
Allergan (AGN), Anadarko Petroleum (APC), Baker Hughes (BHI), Berkshire Hathaway (BRK-A), Corning (GLW), 
Humana (HUM), News Corp (NWS), and Ryanair (RYAAY) all expected to announce results.
Initiations
Discovery Communications (DISCA): The stock is a new Neutral at Cowen & Company.
Upgrades and Downgrades: Life Is Swell For Intel
AudioCodes (AUDC): AUDC is begun at Market Outperform at Rodman & Renshaw, which sets a $5.60 price 
target. The brokerage believes the stock is a way to play the early stages of a secular recovery.
Satcon Technology (SATC): SATC is initiated with a Buy and $6 price objective at Jefferies. (NYSE:JEF)
World Fuel Services (INT): BB&T (NYSE:BBT)  Capital rates World Fuel Services (NYSE:INT)  a new Buy and 
assigns a $40 price objective.
Upgrades
Intel (INTC): Key Dow component Intel (NASDAQ:INTC)  is upgraded to Outperform from Neutral at Macquarie, 
which has a $24.90 price target. See also            What Texas Instruments (NYSE:TXN) Is Telling Tech Investors.
Advanced Micro Devices (AMD): Meanwhile rival semiconductor stock Advanced Micro Devices (NYSE:AMD)  is 
now Neutral from Underperform with a target of $7.70 at Macquarie.
Pfizer (PFE): Pfizer (NYSE:PFE) , also a Dow member, gets moved to Outperform from Market Perform by Sanford 
Bernstein.
Capstead Mortgage (CMO): Saying that the companys CMOs portfolio has turned the corner in terms of replacing 
portfolio runoff, FBR Capital moves Capstead Mortgage (NYSE:CMO PRA)  (NYSE:CMO PRB)  (NYSE:CMO)  to 
Outperform from Market Perform and takes its target up to $12.50 from $12.00.
Capital Source (CSE): Small cap stock Capital Source gets a Buy-from-Hold boost at Citigroup. (NYSE:C)
Gilead Sciences (GILD): RBC Capital raises its Gilead Sciences (NASDAQ:GILD)  rating to Outperform from Sector 
Perform with a price objective of $48.
Skilled Healthcare (SKH): SKH gets hoisted to Market Outperform from Market Perform with a $5 target at JMP 
Securities.
Williams-Sonoma (WSM): Suntrust takes Williams-Sonoma (NYSE:WSM)  to Buy from Neutral.
ENI S.p.A. (E): The stock is now Neutral from Underperform at Credit Suisse.
Eldorado Gold (EGO): EGO gets raised to Outperform from Sector Perform at CIBC World Markets. For related 
content, see            History Is Repeating in Gold Stocks.
Halliburton (HAL): HAL is upgraded to Outperform from Perform at Oppenheimer.
Downgrades
Estee Lauder (EL): EL is lowered to Neutral from Overweight with a $78 target price at Piper Jaffray (NYSE:PJC)  
following Fridays rapid run up.
Anworth Mortgage (ANH): ANH gets moved to Market Perform from Market Outperform at JMP Securities.
Colonial Properties (CLP): CLP is cut to Market Perform from Outperform by brokerage Morgan Keegan primarily 
due to a now-steep valuation.
Upgrades and Downgrades: Life Is Swell For Intel
Vivendi SA: UBS (NYSE:UBS)  reduces its rating on France based media multinational Vivendi (OOTC:VIVEF)  to 
Neutral from Buy ahead of the conglomerates earnings report on November 15th, saying the shares are already up 
by 25% from its earlier 2010 trough.
Manitowoc (MTW): MTW is lowered to Neutral from Buy at Sterne Agee.
Novo-Nordisk A/S (NVO): The stock is now Neutral from Outperform at Credit Suisse.
Rockwell Collins (ROC): RBC Capital reduces its Rockwell Collins (NYSE:COL)  rating to Sector Perform from 
Outperform.
Endeavour Silver (EXK): EXK is downgraded to Underperform from Market Perform by BMO Capital. Also read            
How Low Will Silver Correct?
Schlumberger (SLB): The oil stock is now Perform from Outperform at Oppenheimer.

Ryanair Reducing Operations in Germany because of Ill-Conceived German Tourist Tax
Ryanair Reducing Operations in Germany because of Ill-Conceived German 
Tourist Tax
LawPundit
October 28, 2010 Thursday 8:49 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 LawPundit
Length: 607 words
Byline: Andis Kaulins
Body
   Oct. 28, 2010 (LawPundit delivered by Newstex) -- 
 Government greed for new tax monies, from whatever source, is endless. The new German tourist tax, however, 
threatens to cost much more money than it will bring in. We read:
Ryanair axes 1,000 jobs at German airport - Business News, Business - The Independent
(Hat tip to CaryGEE.)
We fly Ryanair in Europe.
Ryanair makes travel affordable and permits air travel to European destinations which in the old days of outrageous 
air fares were impossible to reach by airplane because of the usurious flight costs.
We say, leave Lufthansa and their inflated fares to the business passengers who can charge their flights to their 
companies as tax write-offs as a cost of doing business. Many private people on the other hand can not afford the 
high Lufthansa (and other carrier) rates for domestic European travel and every extra Euro hurts.
Now Germany is planning to tax the cheap airfare business by assessing a flight surcharge on tourists.
There are any number of things that a nation could or should tax to raise money, but tourists and tourist travel 
would not seem to be the right thing.
Who came up with this crazy scheme in Germany?
Whoever came up with the idea should lay down his or her political career and go do something useful.
Ryanair Reducing Operations in Germany because of Ill-Conceived German Tourist Tax
Ryanair already wrote the following news release in            June (24 June, 2010), warning the German government 
of the consequences of the tourist tax:
 style="color: #996633; font-size: 18px; text-align: center; text-transform: "Ryanair Concerned That Proposed 
German Tourist Tax Will Damage German Tourism, Jobs & Economy INDEPENDENT RESEARCH PROVES 
THAT TOURIST TAXES CAUSE TOURISM DECLINES WHILE NON-TAX COUNTRIES GROW  
Ryanair, the worlds favourite airline, today (24supthsup June) called on the German Govt to abandon its plan to 
introduce a tourist tax on flights which will inevitably lead to steep declines in German air traffic and tourism 
particularly in the German regions. Independent research (by RDC Aviation) proves that seat capacity (and traffic) 
grew strongly in those EU countries which do not impose tourist taxes (Belgium and Holland), while countries which 
impose tourists taxes such as the UK and Ireland continue to suffer steep traffic and tourism declines.
At the conference, Dutch economist Jan Veldhuis, of Amsterdam Aviation Economics, presented a report on the 
Dutch ˜Eco tax which resulted in the Dutch govt scrapping the tax after it estimated the tax would result in up to 
10,000 jobs losses, ??1.2bn is lost tourism, airport and airline revenues and cost the govt up to ??200m in 
unemployment payments while generating as little as ??260m in its first year.
Ryanair warned that any proposed tourist tax in Germany would have a similar impact and cause steep declines in 
traffic at German airports and lead to tourism declines and job losses.
Speaking today in Berlin, Ryanairs Michael OLeary said,
œThe German Govts proposed tourist tax will make Germany an uncompetitive, expensive tourism destination 
which will result in lost visitors, lost jobs, lost tourism revenues and end up costing Germany far more than the tax 
will generate.
œIndependent analysis by RDC Aviation proves that countries which impose tourist taxes continue to see capacity, 
traffic and tourism declines. Growth has returned throughout Europe except in countries such as Ireland and the UK 
which continue to tax tourists instead of welcoming them.
œAs the Dutch experience proves, tourist taxes are deeply damaging and self-defeating and we hope that the 
German Govt will see sense and scrap their plans for a tourist tax."   
 Newstex ID: LPND-5649-50186599

Airline Stocks Wrap Up - Higher: DAL, AMR, LCC
Airline Stocks Wrap Up - Higher: DAL, AMR, LCC
TradersHuddle.com
October 27, 2010 Wednesday 5:02 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 TradersHuddle.com
Length: 309 words
Body
   Oct. 27, 2010 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, October 27th (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index ended the session higher by closing at 
$48.66, which represents 0.97% versus its previous day close. The airline index was mixed with a slight downside 
bias with 6 out of 12 airlines trading higher.
Delta (NYSE:DAL) was the top performer of the sector today closing at $13.78 representing 3.38%. versus the 
previous trading session. Shares of Delta, the largest airline in the world have defined support at $11.12 and 
resistance at $13.65.
AMR (NYSE:AMR) was also among the top performers, closed the trading session at $7.92 representing 3.26% 
from its previous close. AMR, the owner and operator of the 2nd largest U.S. based airline and founder member of 
the Oneworld airline alliance has calculated support and resistance levels at $5.92 and $7.52 respectively. The 
other top performer was US Airways (NYSE:LCC), which closed the trading session at $12 representing 2.3% from 
the previous trading session.
The sector's worst performers include Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) that closed the trading session at $32.49 or -
1.52% from the previous close. Shares of Ryanair, the low fare European airline have defined support at $28.73 
and resistance at $33.34. Also among the worst performers was Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes (NYSE:GOL), 
which closed the trading session at $17.32 representing -1.37% from the previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for December delivery was lower closing the trading session at $81.89 a barrel on the New York 
Mercantile Exchange lower by $-0.66 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by 
traders as they usually correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is 
covered by the price of fuel.
 Newstex ID: TRHD-6828-50141280  
Airline Stocks Wrap Up - Higher: DAL, AMR, LCC

Ryanair cuts 1000 jobs and 150 flights over German air tax increase
Ryanair cuts 1000 jobs and 150 flights over German air tax increase
Gadling
October 27, 2010 Wednesday 3:00 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 Gadling
Length: 192 words
Byline: Scott Carmichael
Body
   Oct. 27, 2010 (AOL Weblogs delivered by Newstex) --
When the German government recently announced a new tourist tax designed to offset their budget woes, many 
airlines announced they'd be forced to cut flights and jobs. So far, Irish low cost carrier            Ryanair has been the 
only one to actually deliver on that threat.
Because of the upcoming tax, the airline is reducing its presence at Frankfurt Hahn airport. At the moment, Ryanair 
operates over 530 flights from Hahn, and will bring that down to 382. In the process, 1000 jobs will be lost. Three of 
the airlines Boeing (NYSE:BA)  737 aircraft will be moved to other airports in their route network. 
From Frankfurt, this also means the loss of routes to Berlin, Prague and Gothenburg. The size of the Ryanair 
operation in Frankfurt is massive - and this reduction in flights means the airline will handle 1 million fewer 
passengers a year. 
If Ryanair is just the first of German based airlines to make cuts like this, the proposed ??8 tourist tax will most 
likely all go to waste on unemployment benefits for fired workers. 
[Photo credit: AFP/Getty Images]

British Airways ' joke offering
British Airways' joke offering
Gulliver
October 27, 2010 Wednesday 12:20 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 Gulliver
Length: 135 words
Body
   Oct. 27, 2010 (The Economist delivered by Newstex) --
MARTIN BROUGHTON'S been eating too much red meat. As if            being rude about the American approach to 
airport security wasn't enough aggression for one speech, the chairman of British Airways also            told a joke 
about Michael O'Leary, the boss of Ryanair.
In Mr Broughtons telling, Mr OLeary goes into a pub, asks for a pint of Guinness and is told by the barman that it 
will cost him £1.
œJust £1? asks Mr OLeary.
œWell, Im a great fan of yours, says the barman.
So Mr OLeary hands over £1 and the barman goes to pour the pint, when he stops and asks: œWould you be 
wanting a glass with that?
Ho ho. (We can't, by the way, credit Mr Broughton with that joke, which has been doing the rounds since at least 
April.)

TradersHuddle.com

Length: 155 words
Body
   Oct. 26, 2010 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, October 26th (TradersHuddle.com) - Shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (OOTC:RYAOF)  
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) booked a new 52 week high today by trading above $33.34, traders are definitely monitoring 
Ryanair's price action to see if this move attracts further buying into the stock.
Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) provides low fare passenger airline services to destinations in Europe.
Ryanair is currently trading -0.36% versus its previous trading session close, and it has calculated support and 
resistance at $28.73 and $33.34 respectively. Clearly with this action this range has been penetrated, and traders 
will be reviewing price action to establish a new tradable range
The overall market index S&P 500 is trading higher by 0.03% from its previous trading close, which means that 
Ryanair stock is underperforming the overall market.

Red Ken Wants To Tax Your Holiday!
Red Ken Wants To Tax Your Holiday!
Iain Dale's Diary
October 22, 2010 Friday 3:10 AM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 Iain Dale's Diary
Length: 236 words
Byline: Iain Dale
Body
   Oct. 22, 2010 (Iain Dale's Diary delivered by Newstex) -- 
 After last months proposal of an 80% tax rate for bankers, Ken Livingstone has come up with another ingenious 
idea - tax people who go on holiday more than once a year! Cos they must be filthy rich, innit.
He made a speech at the Travel Convention in Malta this week (a nice paid gig if ever there was one), declaring 
that overseas holidays were "a class issue". He went on to say that he would like to see a tax imposed after the first 
outbound holiday of the year. He has clearly never heard of the word 'aspiration'.
Overseas holidays are certainly not a class issue in the 21st century. When you can get a £30 return to Rome with 
RyanAir you can hardly claim these holidays are to do with class. Taxing people to go on more than one holiday a 
year is a fatuous idea based on outmoded notions of what constitutes being rich and affluent. People should be free 
to go on as many holidays a year as they like. We are already taxed to the hilt when we abroad and don't need to 
be faced with even more charges.
Anyway, how on earth would it be policed? What constitutes a holiday?
We all know plenty of people who go abroad to visit their families. Does that constitute a holiday? These hairbrain 
ideas just show how out of touch Ken really is with modern day Londoners.
With policies like these, Boris had better watch out. Not.  
 Newstex ID: IAIN-0001-49965768  
Notes

Crude Oil Flat - Airlines Lower: DAL, LUV, RYAAY
Crude Oil Flat - Airlines Lower: DAL, LUV, RYAAY
TradersHuddle.com
October 21, 2010 Thursday 5:02 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 TradersHuddle.com
Length: 313 words
Body
   Oct. 21, 2010 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
 New York, October 21st (TradersHuddle.com) - The NYSE Airline index ended the session lower by closing at 
$47.03, which represents -0.11% versus its previous day close. The airline index was mixed with a slight downside 
bias with 6 out of 12 airlines trading higher.
Delta (NYSE:DAL) was the top performer of the sector today closing at $13.53 representing 4.32%. versus the 
previous trading session. Shares of Delta, the largest airline in the world have defined support at $11.12 and 
resistance at $12.05.
Southwest Airlines Co. (NYSE:LUV) was also among the top performers, closed the trading session at $13.62 
representing 3.5% from its previous close. Southwest Airlines Co. , the domestic discount airline that focuses in 
short haul and high frequency has calculated support and resistance levels at $12.59 and $14.16 respectively. The 
other top performer was Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY), which closed the trading session at $32.77 representing 
0.43% from the previous trading session.
The sector's worst performers include JetBlue Airways (NASDAQ:JBLU) that closed the trading session at $6.62 or 
-4.75% from the previous close. Shares of JetBlue Airways, the New York based discount airline have defined 
support at $6.41 and resistance at $6.75. Also among the worst performers was Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes 
(NYSE:GOL), which closed the trading session at $17.64 representing -2.05% from the previous trading session.
Benchmark crude for November delivery was flat closing the trading session at $81.77 a barrel on the New York 
Mercantile Exchange flat by $0 from the previous trading session. Crude prices are closely watched by traders as 
they usually correlate with the airline stocks, given that a big component of the airlines' cost structure is covered by 
the price of fuel.
