US Airways Group (LCC) and UAL Corp (UAUA) - Zacks #1 Rank Top Performers
US Airways Group (LCC) and UAL Corp (UAUA) - Zacks #1 Rank Top 
Performers
Zacks Investment Research
April 8, 2010 Thursday 1:00 AM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 Zacks Investment Research
Length: 482 words
Byline: James Giaquinto
Body
   Apr. 8, 2010 (Zacks Investment Research delivered by Newstex) -- 
 News reports came out today that US Airways Group, Inc. () and UAL Corporation () were again in merger talks 
now that the recession has ended and the economy seems to be (slowly) recovering. 
?DART(15
);?
 As a result, these two companies occupy the top two spots on the Zacks #1 Rank Top Performers List today. The 
"winner" is LCC with a gain of approximately 10.7%, while UAUA secures the second spot with a gain of 6.75%. 
 It would be the understatement of the year (so far) to simply say that volume for these companies was up on the 
news. Volume for LCC has skyrocketed to more than 52 million shares, compared to the daily average of about 6 
million. Meanwhile, UAUA volume soared to more than 30 million shares, versus the usual 7.5 million. 
 Both companies are part of the transportation - airline industry, which is well-represented on the . Besides US 
Airways Group (NYSE:LCC)  and UAL Corporation, there are 5 other names from that space on the list: Alaska Air 
Group, Inc. (), Delta Air Lines, Inc. (), LAN Airlines S.A. (), Ryanair Holdings plc () and Southwest Airlines Company 
(). (By the way, ALK and DAL are also among the top 10 Top Performers today.) 
 The Deal
 According to the news reports, there's not much to say about the merger yet. The talks have just begun, so a deal 
could be some ways off. Of course, it's also possible that the talks break down all together. 
 An early read from analysts suggest that it might be seen as a positive for the space, since there will be fewer 
flights between a pair of companies that have some overlap in routes. 
US Airways Group
 LCC has put together 7 straight quarters of better-than-expected earnings. More specifically, it has only missed in 
one quarter out of the last 10. In its fourth quarter, the company lost 20 cents per share, which was narrower than 
the Zacks Consensus Estimate and marked a surprise of 60%. 
 The Zacks Consensus Estimate for this year and next is at $1.29 and $1.35 per share, respectively. Both of those 
outlooks have reversed loss estimates over the past 3 months while gaining approximately 14% and nearly 9% in 
30 days. 
US Airways Group (LCC) and UAL Corp (UAUA) - Zacks #1 Rank Top Performers
UAL Corporation
 The overall template for UAUA is similar to LCC, except with different specifics, which is understandable since 
they're both in the same industry and had to deal with the same challenges.
UAL Corporation also strung together 7 straight quarters with earnings surprises. Most recently, the company lost 
$1.05 per share in its fourth quarter, narrower than the Zacks Consensus Estimate, which it beat by more than 28%. 
 The Zacks Consensus Estimate for this year has gained 50% in 30 days to $1.89 per share. Meanwhile, next 
year's target of $2.70 is up nearly 70% in that time. Analysts were expecting losses for both periods three months 
ago. 
Zacks Investment Research

Sector Wrap: Retail, Airlines
Sector Wrap: Retail, Airlines
Market News Video
April 8, 2010 Thursday 8:47 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 Market News Video
Length: 432 words
Body
View Video
 Apr. 8, 2010 (           Market News Video delivered by Newstex) -- 
News out of Greece dampened the mood of investors on Thursday morning as the Greek government continues to 
struggle with its debt.  And Verizon (NYSE:VZ)  (VZ) and Exelon (NYSE:EXC)  (EXC) announced they would be 
forced to take non-cash charges to earnings as a result of the new healthcare legislation passed last month.  With 
trouble brewing in Greece and the US healthcare legislation impacting earnings of even more companies, one 
would expect the markets to be lower this week.  But once again the markets have shown their resilience as the 
Nasdaq has gained 1.4%, the S&P 500 has gained 0.7% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average eeked out a gain of 
0.2% so far.
Investors were encouraged by the positive data from retailers this morning.  Overall, it looks like the early Easter 
has resulted in better-than-expected sales from a number of retailers.  Some of the more notable ones include 
Macy's (M) who posted a 10.8% increase in same-store sales in March, Nordstrom's (JWN) saw same-store sales 
increase by 16.8% and Limited Brands (NYSE:LTD)  (LTD) saw same-store sales increase by 15%.  With the US 
consumer regaining its appetite for spending, investors are hopeful that the economy will continue to grow at a 
strong pace this year.
Shares of the SPDR Retail ETF (XRT) have been on a tear since early February and have gained more than one 
percent this week, including today's modest gains.
And the airline sector has made some noise this week, both positive and negative.  Starting with the positive news, 
United Airlines (UAUA) and US Airways (NYSE:LCC)  (LCC) may consider merging.  A story broke late Wednesday 
that the two airlines may merge and could rival competitor Delta (NYSE:DAL)  (DAL) as the largest US airline.  
However, with the good news, comes the bad.  Travelers could be facing further fees when they want to travel.  
Spirit Airlines announced Tuesday it would begin charging for carry-on luggage, which would be in addition to its 
fees for checked luggage.  And not to be outdone, Ryanair, may begin to charge a toliet fee on shuttle flights in 
Sector Wrap: Retail, Airlines
Europe.  It seems that the airline industry will continue to see what fees it can assess passengers as means of 
boosting quarterly earnings.
Investors bid up shares of the Claymore Airlines ETF (FAA) following the news this week, gaining almost three 
percent so far today.

is 
a 
transcript 
of

video 
published 
at: 
http://www.marketnewsvideo.com?id=201004SectorWrap040810&mv=1.
.

check in, check out
check in, check out
Blood and Treasure
April 7, 2010 Wednesday 10:28 AM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 Blood and Treasure
Length: 204 words
Byline: jamie k
Body
   Apr. 7, 2010 (Blood and Treasure delivered by Newstex) -- 
           An airport worker who helped two women lift the body of a dead relative from a taxi, before they tried to 
check him in for a flight, said he knew he was dead.  
Gitta Jarant and Anke Anusic tried to check in the body of Curt Willi Jarant for a flight to Berlin at Liverpool John 
Lennon Airport on Saturday.  
They said they thought the 91-year-old, who was wearing sunglasses and was in a wheelchair, was asleep.
 Andrew Millea said the man's face fell against his, and it was "ice cold". "I knew straight away that the man was 
dead, but they reassured me that he 'always sleeps like that'," he said.  
Well, theyre economical up in Oldham. It seems like a normal ticket costs less than space in freight. Its the Ryanair 
effect. 
Bodies, incidentally, arent ice cold: they assume ambient temperature, which must have been fairly high if Mr Jarant 
had been fermenting over the course of a 40 mile taxi ride. If he was cold “ and had been dead for 24 hours “ then 
he must have been put in some form of refrigeration. 
Personally Id rather travel with a corpse, assuming it isnt too ripe, than, say a peevish child. Or this chap.

Let's talk some more about Spirit Airlines , bags, toilets and fees
Let's talk some more about Spirit Airlines, bags, toilets and fees
Airline Biz Blog
April 7, 2010 Wednesday 12:52 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 Airline Biz Blog
Length: 240 words
Byline: Terry Maxon/Reporter
Body
   Apr. 7, 2010 (The Dallas Morning News delivered by Newstex) --
1. TripAdvisor.com did an online poll Wednesday to ask people about Spirit Airlines' plans to charge for carry-on 
bags beginning Aug. 1.
Not surprisingly, the 1,750-plus respondents in the non-scientific poll didn't like the idea: 91 percent said they 
wouldn't pay a fee for a carry-on bag.
2. The American Association for Nude Recreation suggest that you don't pack any clothes to go on a trip.
"To avoid added baggage stress as you embark upon a vacation, whose purpose is to de-stress and rejuvenate 
you, plan a Nakation - a vacation to a nudist resort!" AANR executive director Erich Schuttauf said.
"All you'll need for the week (sunscreen, cap, sunglasses, shoes and toiletries) can fit in a small carry on that will fit 
under the seat, avoiding even carry on bag fees," he said.
3. The TravelMail area of the Daily Mail in England, reported Tuesday that Irish carrier Ryanair is moving ahead 
with its plan to put pay toilets on its Boeing (NYSE:BA)  aircraft.
TravelMail quotes Ryanair spokeman Stephen McNamara:
 "By charging for the toilets we are hoping to change passenger behaviour so that they use the bathroom before or 
after the flight. That will enable us to remove two out of three of the toilets and make way for at least six extra seats 
on board." 
Ryanair is looking a fee of a pound ($1.53) or euro ($1.34), whatever you have on you.
Let's talk some more about Spirit Airlines , bags, toilets and fees

We have some reactions to Spirit Airlines ' fee for carry-on bags
We have some reactions to Spirit Airlines' fee for carry-on bags
Airline Biz Blog
April 6, 2010 Tuesday 2:16 PM EST
Copyright 2010 Newstex LLC
All Rights Reserved
Newstex Web Blogs
Copyright 2010 Airline Biz Blog
Length: 612 words
Byline: Terry Maxon/Reporter
Body
   Apr. 6, 2010 (The Dallas Morning News delivered by Newstex) --
Spirit Airlines said Tuesday morning that it will charge for carry-on bags beginning Aug. 1. Here are some reactions.
Jami Counter, senior director of            TripAdvisor Flights:
 I think that this move by Spirit may cross the line for American travelers who are already near the breaking point 
due to rising checked baggage fees, and that other domestic carriers will be hard pressed to follow suit in the near-
term. It's interesting that the program will not kick in until August, perhaps giving Spirit time to cut the program if 
there's significant backlash from customers. 
In any case, it's going to take some time for air travelers to get accustomed to the idea of an airline charging for 
carry-on baggage. While there may be a big enough customer base out there willing to suffer a wide array of add-
on fees in exchange for rock bottom fares, it's likely that this move will alienate many fliers.
I'd expect other domestic carriers to sit back and watch to see how this move by Spirit plays out. If there's not a 
strong customer backlash, other carriers may be tempted to match the move given the challenging industry revenue 
environment. At the end of the day though, I do think this is a step too far for the traveling public and other carriers 
won't follow Spirit's lead on this.
Airfarewatchdog.com president George Hobica:
 The real question is, will other airlines follow, and will this actually be good for air travel? Planes will load faster if 
people don't bring carryons on board. The carryon fees are actually higher than checked bag fees now on Spirit, so 
apparently Spirit is trying to get people not to bring carryons. 
And the other question is when will more shoes drop? When will we finally see a US airline dare to charge for using 
a credit or debit card, and who will be the first to eliminate airport check-in counter staff, forcing passengers to show 
up at the airport with a pre-printed boarding pass and pre-paid luggage fees, then proceed to a conveyor belt, show 
We have some reactions to Spirit Airlines ' fee for carry-on bags
their fee payment, and drop their bags themselves on a conveyor belt - and proceed to the gate. No human 
interaction necessary.
Aubrey Cohen,            Aerospace News, Seattlepi.com:
 I actually think this makes sense, in that I agree with the idea of allowing people to pay for what they need and not 
pay for what they don't. (Although charging for bathrooms goes too far. Do you hear me, Ryanair?) 
Also, making it cheaper -- or at least the same price -- to check a bag will eliminate the extra time and hassle 
caused by people trying to fit their camping chests into already overstuffed overhead bins.
Rick Seaney, CEO of            FareCompare.com:
 Well, I predicted this was coming - and sadly, I was right. 
Tom Belden,            Winging Itblog, Phladelphia Inquirer:
 There is no charge yet for carrying on a cane or coat, or if you're wearing clothes when boarding (perhaps that will 
be next, since clothing adds to weight, which causes an airplane to burn more fuel, which increases an airline's 
costs, which otherwise might require an increase in ticket prices, which would be unfair to all those who choose to 
wear clothes while traveling, right?)  
Chris Elliott, ConsumerTraveler.com:
 [Chief financial officer Ken] McKenzie is suggesting that passengers asked for these changes. That's nonsense. I 
don't know of anyone who wanted to pay for a carry-on bag. What's worse, I hear echoes of this when I speak with 
people at the Transportation Department: You should only have to pay for what you use. 
How far can they take that line of reasoning? All the way to the pay toilets?
 Newstex ID: DA-2642-43601467
